editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: Sir Courtly Nice: OR, It cannot Be.
As it is Acted by His MAJESTIES Servants.
LONDON, Printed by H. H. Jun. for R. Bently, in Ruſſel-ſtreet, Covent-Garden, and Joſ. Hindmarſh, at the Golden-Ball over againſt the Royal Exchange in Cornhill. M.DC.LXXXV.

row.cell: Leonora's Brother, in love with Violante.
A Fop, overcurious in his Diet and Dreſs: In love with Leonora.
A young Man of Quality and Fortune, his Rival.
A moroſe, ill natur'd, negligent Fellow, in love with Violante.
A Lady of Quality and Fortune, in love with Belguard.
Belguard's Siſter, in love with Farewel.
Leonora's Governeſs—an old Amorous, envyous Maid.

div.head: To his Grace the Duke of ORMOND, Lord Steward of His Majeſties Houſhold, Chancellor of the Ʋniverſity of Oxford.
div.p: THis Comedy was Written by the Sacred Command of our late moſt Excellent King, of ever bleſſed and beloved Memory. I had the great good Fortune to pleaſe Him often at His Court in my Maſque, on the Stage of Tragedies and Comedies, and ſo to advance my ſelf in His good opinion; an Honour may render a wiſer Man than I vain; for I believe he had more equals in extent of Dominions than of Underſtanding. The greateſt pleaſure he had from the Stage was in Comedy, and he often Commanded me to Write it, and lately gave me a Spaniſh Play called No Puedeſer: Or, It cannot Be. out of which I took part o' the Name, and deſign o' this. I received the Employment as a great Honour, becauſe it was difficult; requiring no ordinary skill and pains to build a little Shallop, ſit only for the Spaniſh South Seas, into an Engliſh Ship Royal; but I believe my ſelf able for the Work, becauſe he thought ſo, who underſtood me and all Men, better than I only knew my ſelf, encourag'd by Royal judgment that never was miſtaken, I have attained a ſucceſs I never ſhould have met with, had I only followed my own feeble Genius, which often deceives me. That I may enjoy the little fortune I have got with the better reputation, and not ramble the World like a blind Author, obſerving none but my ſelf, I make this humble Application to your Grace. I am ſure all the World will approve my choice. I cannot be guilty of Flattery if I would; nor ſlander Wit (if I had any) by fulſome and wanton Paintings. Here will be no Tryal of skill how I can praiſe, Nature has done it to my Hands, and devis'd and expos'd finer Ideas, than I am able to Tranſlate. A gracefulneſs of Perſon, excellence of Underſtanding, largeneſs of Heart, a Loyalty, Gallantry, Integrity, Humility, and many Qualities above my deſcription. Fortune alſo has been more wiſe than uſual, She frequently honours and enriches others to her own diſgrace—but here She ſhares in the Praiſe, and Commends her own Wiſdome, in what She beſtows on your Grace. She has advanc'd Honour in Advancing you, Titles, Greatneſs and Command may be proved, they have attained you. Wealth has a value in your Hands, 'Tis no vile pardon, poor flatterer, ſervile Lacquey, wretched Priſoner; but excellent Miniſter of a juſt wiſe and liberal Prince. Shou'd I mention all the Qualities, that have long gained you the higheſt Honours from Prince and People, I ſhould rather ſeem to deſcribe a Province than a Man; for what ſingle Province can afford what are at once in your Grace, a General, a Stateſman, Courtier, and all in perfection; and which is rare in ſuch company, a Martyr. What has your Grace both done and ſuffered, for our Religion, Laws, Liberties and Honour? And not only in the former times of Rebellion, but the latter of Confuſion? When the pretended Proteſtants of the times, out of their Zeal againſt all Popiſh Doctrines, abhorring you for adhering to good Works.

As an Engliſh-man, I am bound in juſtice, to pay you all the Honours I can. You have been an Ornament, and ſupport to the Crown and Church of England, both in your Perſon and Poſterity. Many great Men no doubt have ſprung from your example, but none equalling thoſe deſcended from your ſelf. The late brave Earl of Oſſery, advanced the Honour of our Nation, both by Sea and Land. 'Tis hard to ſay in which Element he made us moſt renown'd, and for which vertue. He was no more to be vanquiſhed by falſhood than fear; Loyalty, Fidelity, and Gallantry, are Vertues inſeparable from the Houſe of Ormond; we find e'm in every branch of it, and at all ſeaſons. The Earl of Arran, Attacked in the late days of Confuſion, a Bloody, Popular, and Formidable Error in its Camp, Fortified and Defended by all the ſtrength of England; and for ever ſecur'd his own, and ſo much of the Publick reputation as was entruſted to him; managing that charge with the ſame Wiſdom, Juſtice, and Fidelity he has done the Kingdom of Ireland, and many other great Commands, for the Honour and Service of the King. In the Young Earl of Oſſery we have great aſſurances, the Grandfather and Father ſhall live in him, and receive the laſt rewards of Vertue Men are capable of in this World, to have their Honour and Happineſs extend beyond their own beings. And herein the Hiſtory of your Grace ſeems a Comment on the Fifth Commandment, you have always Honoured the Father of your Country, and your Days of Honour continue long in the Land, in your own Perſon, and your Illuſtrious Race. A uſeful Preſident to England.

That I may approve my ſelf an honeſt and grateful Engliſh-man, is one reaſon of my Addreſs: I have alſo other obligations on me. Your Grace has been a Princely patron and encourager of Poetry; a Pleaſant but Barren Country where my Genius and inclination has caſt me. I am entangled among the inclinations of it, though it affords nothing but a good Ayre, a little vain reputation, and we muſt climb for it, and ſhall miſs it too, if envy or ill nature can hinder us. There were no living, if ſome great Men elevated not only in Quality but Underſtanding above the reſt of the World, did not Protect us from theſe Barbarians, becauſe they know us. I beſeech your Grace then give me leave to pay my Duty to you. Many and great are your Revenues in Honour, in the Camp, the Court, the Church, and the whole Common-wealth of Learning. The Poet may be employed as well as the Hiſtorian. I have made but a ſmall Collection, but I have put it in hands that I hope will not ſoon embezle it. This Comedy has rais'd it ſelf ſuch a fortune in the World, I believe it will not ſoon run away. Give it leave to Honour it ſelf with your great Name, and me with the Title of,

closer.signed: Your Graces moſt Humble and Obedient Servant. John Crown.

div.head: The Prologue.
div.l: WHat are the Charmes, by which theſe happy Iſles
Hence gain'd Heaven's brighteſt and eternal ſmiles?
What Nation upon Earth beſides our own,
But by a loſs like ours had been undone?
Ten Ages ſcarce ſuch Royal worths diſplay
As England loſt, and found in one ſtrange Day.
One hour in ſorrow and confuſion hurld,
And yet the next the envy of the World.
Nay we are bleſt, in ſpite of us 'tis known,
Heavens choice for Us was better than our own.
To ſtop the bleſſings that oreflow this day,
What heaps o' Rogues we pild up in the way?
We choſe fit tooles againſt all good to ſtrive,
The ſawcieſt, lewdeſt, Proteſtants alive.
They wou'd have form'd a bleſſed Church indeed,
Upon a Turn-coate Doctor's lying Creed.
To know if e're he took Degree is hard,
'Tis thought he'l have one in the Palace Yard,
Plot ſwallowers ſure will Drink no more ſtuff down,
From that foul Pitcher when his Ears are gone.
Let us rely on Conſcience, not on Cheats,
On Heavens wiſdom, not on Juglers feats.
How greatly Heaven has our great loſs ſupplyed?
'Tis no ſmall Vertue heales a Wound ſo wide.
Nay in ſo little time to reer our Head,
To our own wonder, and our Neighbours dread.
They ſee that Valour Crown'd with regal Power,
They oft have ſeen what Lawrels Crown'd before.
Verſe is too narrow for ſo Great a Name,
Far ſounding Seas hourly repeat His Fame.
Our Neighbours vanquiſh'd Fleets oft wafted o're,
His Name to theirs and many a trembling Shore;
And we may go by His great Conduct led
As far in Fame as our Forefathers did.
At home he milder ways to Glory choſe,
God like, by Patience he ſubdued his Foes;
Now they and their deſigns are Ruin'd all,
Beneath their fallen, accurſt, Excluding Wall.
Theſe are not all the bleſſings of this Iſle,
Heaven on our Nation in a Queen does ſmile.
Whoſe Vertue's Grace by Beauty ſhine ſo bright,
All the Fair Sex to Vertue She'l invite;
And all the Clouds turn to a glorious Day,
By that Illuſtrious paire's united ray,
Who both Reform and Grace Us by their ſway.

div.head: Epilogue.
div.l: 'TIs a hard Caſe, an Audience now to pleaſe,
For every Pallat's ſpoyl'd with ſome Diſeaſe.
Poor Plays as faſt as Women now decay,
They'r ſeldom car'd for after the firſt day;
How often have I heard true wit call'd ſtuff,
By Men with nothing in their Brains but Snuff?
Each Shante Spark, that can the Faſhion hit,
Place his Hat thus, role full Forſooths a Wit;
And thinks his Cloaths allows him judge of it.
The City Gallant, the Exchange being done,
Takes Sword at Temple-Bar which Nice ſtuck on.
Comes here and paſſes for a Beaugarzoon.
Audacious Vizards too, ſo faſt do grow,
You hardly can the Virtuous from 'em know.
Nay Parents now not likely can endure,
Their Childrens faults, but what is worſe procure.
Of Old the Mother full of Parent ſway,
Kept Miſs a Vaſſal to her work all day;
And to the Wooing Spark Miſs was not brought,
But ſome fine Golden thing her wheedle wrought:
Now you ſhall meet young Lady and her Mother,
Rambling in Hackny-Coaches maſqu't together;
Yes, and to ſay the truth, to work they go,
Fine work but—ſuch as they will never ſhew.
Ʋnleſs ſome Nott to draw a Fool to Wed,
And then he finds Miſs rare at work a Bed.
But the Grand Randevouz is kept of late,
Exact at Nine, hard by o're Chocholate,
Sad fate, that all the Chriſtian Youth o'th' Nation,
Should be oblig'd to Jews for Procreation.
Nay, what is worſe, that's, if reports be true,
Many a Chriſtian Gallant there turns Jew;
That is, ſo oft ſome rotten Strumpet plyes him,
The Chirurgion's forc't at laſt to Circumciſe him.
Our Bridges-ſtreet is grown a Strumpet Fair,
Where higling Bawds do Palmb their rotten Ware.
There Fowler like the watching Gallant Pores
Behind his Glove, to get a ſhot at Whores;
And from his tongue lets flye ſuch charming Words,
That ſtrait he carrys off the wounded Birds.
Another waits above in the great Room,
Till a new Cargozoon of Strumpets come.
There by three Glaſſes plac't the Affected Dunce,
Acts you Four Courtly-Nices all at once;
Our Gallerys too, were finely us'd of late,
Where rooſting Maſques ſat cackling for a Mate:
They came not to ſee Plays but act their own,
And had throng'd Audiences when we had none.
Our Plays it was impoſſible to hear,
The honeſt Country Men were forc't to ſwear:
Confound you, give your bawdy prating o're,
Or Zounds, I'le fling you i' the Pitt, you bawling Whore—
This Comedy throws all that lewdneſs down,
For Virtuous Liberty is pleas'd alone:
Promotes the Stage to' th' ends at firſt deſign'd,
As well to profit, as delight the Mind.

div.head: A COMEDY Call'd Sir Courtly Nice: OR, It Cannot Be.
ACT. I.
div.stage: Enter at ſeveral Doors Leonora and Violante. Scene, Lord Bellguard's Houſe.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: MY Dear—

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: My Dear, how is it with thee? What amendment in thy Brothers humour, and thy condition?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: None.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Oh! thou break'ſt my heart, for I love him extreamly, and am, I think, as well belov'd by him; but whil'ſt he has this Diſeaſe upon him ſo mortal to Liberty, dare venture on him no more, than if he had the Plague, or any other Diſtemper dangerous to Life. For what is life without Liberty? To be his Wife is worſe than to be a Ghoſt, for that walks and enjoys a little chat ſometimes, but I muſt be laid by a Conjurer call'd a Husband for my whole life, I would not be a Queen on the tearms; no nor on any tearms, becauſe a Queen is confin'd to Forms, ſo fond am I of Liberty; but next to that I love your Brother; I wou'd give all the World to cure him, is there no way?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: None that I know off.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Muſt we then be for ever unhappy, I in the loſs of him, and you in Eternal Slavery?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I might have Liberty, but on ſuch tearms—

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: What Tearms?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Marriage with ſuch a Coxcomb, you know him—Sir Courtly Nice.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: A tempting Man, he has a vaſt eſtate.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: But incumber'd.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: With what?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: A Fop, 'tis morgag'd to a thouſand expenſive Follies, if it were not, I wou'd not drink water for the ſake of a fine Bowl chain'd to the Well. The Youth I love has a fair and free Eſtate.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Mr. Farewel is it not?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: The ſame.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Ay, but he's forbidden Fruit.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I know it to my ſorrow.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: What's the reaſon?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Hiſtory muſt tell you. There has been a pique between our Families ſince the Conqueſt; none were thought truly of our Blood, that had not that Scurvy in it; becauſe mine began to ſweeten, my Father almoſt ſuſpected my Legitimacy; and left me no Fortune but on condition I retain'd the Ancient mark of our Houſe.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: There ariſes then your Brothers great Authority. He has the diſpoſal of your Fortune, by conſequence of your Perſon; Fortune is all Men ſeek now. They are ſo cow'd from Marriage, they will go Voluntiers into a Battle but muſt be preſt to marriage; and 'tis the Shilling does it.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Too true, But I believe Mr. Farewel of a more generous temper, he addreſſes ſtill.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: It may be he does not know how it is with you, you have the Fame of Ten thouſand pound.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: And the Money too, if I marry with my Brothers conſent, not elſe.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: That's hard, but Mr. Farewel has enough for you both.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Ay, if he will venture on me; yet if he will I know not how to come at him, I am ſo watch'd, not only at home but abroad. I never ſtir out but as they ſay the Devil does, with Chains and Torments. She that is my Hell at home, is ſo abroad.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: A new Woman.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: No, an old Woman, or rather an old Devil; nay worſe than an old Devil, an old Maid.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Oh! there's no Fiend ſo envious.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Right, ſhe will no more let young People ſin, that the Devil will let 'em be ſav'd, out of envy to their happineſs.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Who is ſhe?

sp.speaker: Leo
sp.p: One of my own Blood, an Aunt.

sp.speaker: Vio
sp.p: I know her, ſhe of thy bloud? ſhe has not had a drop of it, theſe Twenty Years; the Devil of envy ſuck'd it all out, and left verjuice in the roome.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: True, this Aunt hangs on me like a daily Ague; but I had rather endure her, then be cur'd by ſuch a nonſenſical Charm as Sr. Courtly is. And nothing elſe can be applyed to me; for to aſſiſt my governing Aunt, there is a whole Army of Spies in the Houſe; and over them two Spies General: And there my Brother thinks he ſhews a Maſter-piece of Policy.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Why? what are they?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Two, that will agree in nothing but one anothers confuſion. The one is a poor Kinſman of ours, ſo fierce an Enemy to Fanaticks, that he cou'd eat no other meat; and he need no other Fire than himſelf to roaſt 'em, for he's always in a flame when he comes near 'em, his Name is Hot-head.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: And I warrant thee the other is a Fanatick.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Oh! a moſt Zealous Scrupulous one; with a conſcience ſwadled ſo hard in its Infancy by ſtrict Education, and now Thump'd and Cudgel'd ſo ſore with daily Sermons and Lectures, that the weak ricketty thing can endure nothing.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Certainly theſe two, muſt make you ſport.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Oh! their faces, Dreſſes, Names are jeſts. The Fanatick's Name's Teſtimony.
Where is my Lord? Where's my Lord?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Oh! I hear my Cholerick Couſin Hot-head.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Where's my Lord? Where's my Lord, I ſay?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: What wou'd you do with my Lord?

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Call him to an account if he were not my Couſin, cut his pate, it may be Cudgel him. Heaven be thank'd to Cudgel a Lord is no Scandalum Magnatum.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: What's the reaſon of all this anger?

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: He affront's me, he invites me to live in his houſe, and then keeps a Fanatick to make a jeſt o' me. He knows I ſweat when I ſee one.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: May be he has occaſion for one.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: What occaſion? He is not in a Plot, is he? Fanaticks are good for nothing elſe that I know of.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Why not? Toads are good for ſomething.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Ay, when they are hang'd and dryed, ſo is no Fanatick. He is ſuch a canker'd Rogue, he does miſchief when he's hang'd; let him ſpread Ink upon Paper and it raiſes bliſters.—But here the Rogue is.
[Sirrah! Sirrah, What's your buſineſs in this Houſe, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: What Authority have you to examine me, Friend?

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Friend, you Dog! call me. Friend, I'le knock you down Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: Poor Soul—poor Soul—

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p:
You are an Impudent Raſcal to call me poor Soul—Sirrah, I have a Loyalty and a good Conſcience, and that's a better Eſtate, than any
of your Party have; and if you live in the Houſe with me, I'le ſettle it on you with a Pox to you.

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: Yes, Mr. Hot-head I know you well enough, I know you would hang us all if you could.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: I need not Sirrah, for Heaven be prais'd now you begin to hang your ſelves; I knew when Tyburn was beſtow'd upon the Prieſts and Jeſuits, the Fanaticks and Re-publicans wou'd not long be without it, for they are very fond of all Church Lands, come, Sirrah, if you live here, I'le make you turn over a new leaf, I'le make you go to Church, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: That's more than you do your ſelf Mr. Hot-head, you go not often to Church.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: What then? I'm for the Church, Sirrah. But you are againſt the Church, and againſt the Miniſters, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: I cannot be Edifyed by 'em, they are formal, weak, ignorant, poor Souls—Lord help 'em—poor Souls.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Ignorant? you're an impudent Raſcal to call Men o' their Learning Ignorant; there's not one in a hundred of 'em, but has taken all his Degrees at Oxford, and is a Doctor, you Sot you.

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: What ſignifies Oxford? can't we be ſav'd unleſs we go to Oxford?

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Oxford don't lye out o' the road to Heaven; you Aſs.

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: Pray what do they learn at Oxford? only to ſtudy Heathens; they'l talk of Ariſtotle in the publick, they may be aſham'd to name Ariſtotle among civil People.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Oh! you Sot.

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: Our Miniſters are powerful Men. Oh! Forſooth I wiſh to Leo. you were under one of our Miniſters; you wou'd find they wou'd pierce you forſooth; they wou'd go to your inward parts.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: This Rogue is talking Bawdy.

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: They would ſhew you the great—great ſinfulneſs of ſin, that ſin is one of the ſinfulleſt things in the whole World.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: You ſenceleſs Raſcal, what ſhould be ſinful but ſin? what ſhould be fooliſh but a Fool?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Are not theſe a ridiculous Couple?

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: Come this is very provoking, and very Prophane; I ſhall have a ſad time on't in this wicked Family.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Wicked! Sirrah: What wickedneſs do you ſee in this Family?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Ay, Mr. Teſtimony, now we are all concern'd, what Vices do you find among us?

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: Suppoſe I ſee not many Vices, morality is not the thing; the Heathens had morality, and forſooth would you have your Coachman or your Footman to be no better Men than Seneca?

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: A Coachman a better Man then Seneca?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I wou'd have him be a better Coachman than I believe Seneca was.

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: Ay, and a better Chriſtian too, or woe be to him. But truly I ſee great wantonneſs even in your ſelf forſooth,—the very Cook debauches you.—

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: How? call the Cook!—Cook!—Cook!—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: The Cook debauch me, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: I mean by pampring you, Morning, Noon, and Night with one wanton kickſhaw or another.—
You Coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Sot.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Raſcal, I thought the Cook had layn with my Couſin—Sirrah, you deſerve to have your bones broke. Well Sirrah, ſince you find my Lords. Table is too Iuſty, I'le have it guelded; I'le make you keep Lens, and faſt Wednesdays and Fridays.

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: I will not, I abhor it, 'tis Popery.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Then you ſhall faſt Tueſdays and Thursdays.

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: And then the Family will ſlander me, and ſay I do it out o' contradiction,—I will not do it, I do not love to grieve the weak.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: To grieve the ſtrong thou mean'ſt, thy own ſtrong ſtomack.

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: You are offenſive.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: I will be more. I will watch you Sirrah, and know why my Lord feeds ſuch Raſcals.

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: I tarry not for his feeding, the Family is a ſad Family, and I tarry out of pure Bowels.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Out of empty Bowels, which you have a mind to fill, and it may be you may fill other empty bellys, I mean among the Wenches, ſome of you Godly Rogues play ſuch tricks ſome times. I'le watch you Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: And I'le watch you, my Spirit riſes at this Man exceedingly.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Theſe are a pleaſant Couple.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Is not my Brother politick? Theſe are to ſee no Proviſions for wantonneſs be conveigh'd to me from abroad, and be ſure they will not agree to deceive him. And that I may have none at home, My Brother will not venture a handſome Servant in the houſe; he ſwears he will not be Brother in Law to er'e a Butler or Footman in England; and he has cull'd for his Family, the moſt choice peices of deformity he cou'd find in the Nation. I believe they are now altogether in the Pantry, and my Aunt among 'em diſtributing their Breakfaſts—the Monſters will be worth ſeeing—open the Door.—
sp.stage: The Scene is drawn, and a Company of Crooked, Wither'd, ill-look'd Fellows are at breakfaſt, and Aunt with them.

sp.speaker: Aunt.
sp.p: How now? Who open'd the Door without my leave? Neice, this is one o' your Girliſh tricks, will you always be a Child? Will you never learn ſtaidneſs and gravity, notwithſtanding the perpetual Counſel you have from me, the perpetual diſpleaſure I ſhew at all ſort of youthful Follies; do not you know how I hate impertinent Youth?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Or any ſort o' youth to my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p:
Do not I always tell you how ſine a thing it is to be Grave; that Youth with Gravity is very paſſable, and almoſt eſteem'd equal with years? Very wiſe Perſons will not be aſham'd to match with Grave Youth; daily experience ſhews it, and will you never leave? Fye—fye—fye—I
wou'd not for the World any Wiſe Sober Perſon o' Quality that has an Inclination for you, ſhou'd ha' ſeen this rudeneſs in you, to Expoſe your Aunt in this manner, in her undreſs; it might ha' created in him an averſion for you.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: An averſion to me, to ſee your ill dreſs?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Madam, I hope you'l pardon the liberty I take in your preſence.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Oh! good Madam.—

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Oh! Madam—pardon me—I know I commit a Soleciſm in good Manners,—but you are a Lady that has a great deal o' goodneſs, and a great deal o' worth.—

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Oh! ſweet Madam!—

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Oh! Madam! our Family has found it—you are pleas'd to Honour us with your Friendſhip. We may venture to expoſe our Frailties before you, Madam, you'l be ſo good to pardon—Madam—

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Oh! Madam!—

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Well really Madam—I wonder where my Neice learns her wantonneſs, we are the moſt reſerv'd Family in the World. There were Fourteen Siſters of us, and not one of us married.—

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I'ſt poſſible?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: To your great grief—

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: We were all ſo reſerv'd. Oh! Madam! no Man durſt preſume to think of us;—I never had three love Letters ſent to me in my whole life.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Oh! ſtrange!

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Oh! we were very reſerv'd. Well Madam I am very much out o' Countenance to appear thus before you.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Oh! Madam, every thing becomes you Madam.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Oh! you are very obliging Madam.—Do you hear Neece—learn o' this Lady?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: To flatter you.—

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Madam I am extream unfortunate, the affairs o' the Family call me away from your ſweet Converſation.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: the misfortune is mine, Madam.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Oh! ſweet Madam your moſt humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Your humbler Servant dear Madam. Ha! ha! ha! what Exit Aunt. ridiculous peice of Antiquity is this? Thy Brother has a great Honour for his Family ſince he will keep ſuch a relick of his Anceſtors as this.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: All the houſe is of a piece.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Nay if thou learn'ſt lewdneſs at home, thou haſt a great Genius to it.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Well, what do you think of my condition?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I like it.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Like it?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Ay, for I perceive your Brother has put the whole force of his Wit into this Form of Government; now if we can baffle it, he will find it is a dream fit for nothing but Utopia; and never torment himſelf and his Friends with it any more, then he'l be a faultleſs Creature, and all of us happy in our Loves, Here he comes.
Your Servant good my Lord.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Your moſt humble Servant Madam.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: My Lord, why do you call him Lord? he's a Doctor and curing me o' the Palpitation o' the heart, Falling-ſickneſs, Convulſions in the Eyes, and other ſuch Diſtempers.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: A Doctor? a Quack by his falſe Medecines; ſhortly we ſhall ſee him mount the Stage, or ſtand at the Old—Exchange and cry a Cure for your Horns, a Cure for your Horns.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I'm glad to ſee you ſo pleaſant Madam.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: How can I otherwiſe chuſe my Lord, and ſee your Family and Government?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Faith, Madam he that will have a Garden muſt incloſe it, and cover tender Plants: This is a very blaſting age to Vertue, 'twill not thrive without a covering.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Ay, but my Lord, you force your ground too much, what Horns wou'd not grow in your Soyle? When wou'd not your Forehead ſprout? Were I your Wife and thus kept, I ſhou'd ſpread like a Vine, and all the Walls in England wou'd not hold me.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I'm not o' that opinion, Madam.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Why ſhou'd you think better o' me than your Siſter?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I judge very well of her, but muſt ſpeak freely I think few Women may be truſted in this life, this World is, and ever was a great brothel; where? or with whom may a Woman be truſted? with ancient Ladies; they are the chief Beauty Merchants, venders of fine Love.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Ladies o' that Profeſſion.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Oh! the moſt excellent, and moſt in Employ. Pedling Women cry Scotch Cloath of a groat a yard, ſtuff only fit for Footmen. But wou'd you have fine Beauty, Choice of Beauty, and with eaſe Security and Decency, go to your Lady Merchants; in Common houſes the work is manag'd as ſlovenly as Religion in Conventicles, enough to put one out of conceit with it; but in Brothels o' Quality, Iniquity is carried on with that venerable order wou'd intice any one to Devotion.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Fye! fye!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And with that ſecurity. A Man may there enjoy a Lady whilſt her Husband holds her Cards.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: And ſhall the Lady o' the houſe know o' theſe things?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And manage 'em too; break the Lady to the Lovers hands; that's the advantage o' Quality, if a young Lady has not a natural amble, a poor Bawd cannot have acceſs to teach her.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: What can a Lady o' Quality propound by ſuch doings?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Oh! many things. As Preſents; and Pleaſures. She has her houſe full of good Company, her Ears full of wanton Stories; her Eye full of tempting Sights, and now and then her Lips get a cloſe kiſs. Oh! Madam! do you think it does not warm an Elderly Lady's blood, to have a brisk young Spark always by her ſide? he is her Liquour of life, and though ſhe never gets a full draught, a taſt chears her heart.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Who are theſe Ladies? where do they live?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Oh! you'd feign be acquainted with 'em? no ſuch matter; and yet I'le tell you where they live.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Almoſt every where; where there is an Amorous Aunt, or over-indulgent Mother.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Mothers? will Mothers corrupt their Daughters?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ay, or if they wont Daughters will corrupt their Mothers. Things are ſo inverted, that Ladies who were honeſt all their Youth to be like their Mothers, turn lew'd in their old Age to be like their Daughters. There never was ſuch an open and general War made on Virtue; young ones of Thirteen will pickeere at it, and by that time they are twenty, they are riſen to be Strumpets General, and march in publick with their Baggage, with Miſs, and Maſs, and Nurſe and Maid, and a whole train of Reformade ſinners, expecting the next Cully that falls.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: You talk of paltry huſſes.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Very good Gentlewomen.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Gentlewomen o' thoſe employments.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ay, purchaſe 'em. I have known a fair young Lady give all her Fortune to attend a Man o' Quality in his Bed-Chamber; be his chief Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Suppoſe ſo, what's all this to me? If they be bad muſt I be ſo?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Truly Siſter, a rambling Woman let her be never ſo good a manager, will be apt to bring her Vertue as a Traveller does his Money, from a Broad peice to a braſs Farthing: But ſay ſhe does not, is reputation nothing? and let me tell you, Reputation will hang looſe upon a galloping Lady; you may as well go among high Winds and not be ruffled, as among Men and not have your good Name blown over your Ears.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Thoſe Winds blow where they liſt. A Woman is not ſecue rat home from Cenſure.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: But you muſt allow a Jewel is not ſo ſafe in a Crow'd as when lock'd up.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Lock'd up? do you think to lock me up?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I think to ſecure thee, my dear Siſter.

l.hi: Women like Cheney ſhou'd be kept with care,
One flaw debaſe's her to common • are.

div.head: ACT II.
div.stage: Scene Violante's houſe. Enter Violante' and a Servant.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: IS Mr. Farewel coming?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Yes Madam, he's juſt at the Door.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: That's well, if this brisk young Fellow, has but Love enough to undertake this work, and Wit enough to go through with it, we ſhall all be happy.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Where's your Lady? Madam, your moſt humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Your Servant Mr. Farewel; you are a happy Man, young, rich, and in the Ladies Favours.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: I'm glad to hear that, Madam; who are theſe Ladies Madam,? a day, and hour of Youth and good Fortune is precious; and Ladies like Birds muſt be aim'd at whilſt they hop about us, miſs that opportunity you may looſe 'em for ever. Therefore the Ladies, good Madam, quick, quick, for if you defer but half an hour, they'l be in love with ſome body elſe.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: No Mr. Farewel, there is one Lady more Conſtant, you'l own it when I name her; my Lord Belguard's delicate young Siſter. What ſay you to her?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: I adore her.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: And dare you attempt her?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Dare I?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Ay, for do not you know you are the only Man forbidden her.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Do I know of what Race I am, Madam? Never was ſuch a pack of Fops as my Lord Belguard's Anceſtors and mine. They lov'd wrangling more than we do intriguing; kept Lawyers inſtead o' Wenches, and begot upon their bodies, a thouſand illegitimate Law Suits, the Terms they obſerv'd as duly as the River does t • e Tydes, and Land was carried too and frow, as mud is in the Thames. Nor were their quarrels ſo bitter about Land, as place; ſo big were their great hearts, they cou'd not come into one Room together, for fear of looſing place. My Lord Belguard's Father to end the difference, moſt piouſly endeavours to be a better Man than any of his Anceſtors. That is to ſay a Lord.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: And then the ſtrife ended?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p:
Was more enflam'd. For my Lord was more inſolent, as having Authority under the Broad Seal to be proud, by Conſequence my Father more enrag'd; and both the old Gentlemen contended who ſhou'd have the greateſt Eſtate in malice, and attain'd to be very conſiderable, and when
they dyed, endeavourd to ſettle it all upon us. But truly the young Lady and I moſt prodigally conſum'd all our Portions at one look, and agreed to cut of the wicked Entail.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: You did well, but how will you accompliſh your deſires? her Brother has ſuch guards upon her.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Oh! 'tis Decreed! nor ſhall thy Fate oh! Brother! reſiſt my Vow, though Guards were ſet on Guards, till their confounded Coxcombs reach'd the Skies, I'd or'e 'em all—

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: You are in a Rapture.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Ten thouſand when ever I think of her.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: But how will you do this?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: I have leagu'd with a Witch; at leaſt a young Fellow that has more tricks than a Witch; he was a poor Scholler at Oxford, but expell'd for ſtudying the Black Arts.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: For Conjuring?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, not only any Mans Pigs or Poultry, but Wife or Daughter into his Chamber. Nothing cou'd ſcape him, and he ſcap'd every thing. The Proctors watch'd more diligently for him, then a Benefice, and cou'd never catch him. The Grave Doctors abhor'd him worſe than a Haereſie, and ſtudyed more to keep him out of their Families, but he confuted their Skill, and they cou'd no more light upon him than on a jeſt.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I long to ſee him.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: I ordered him to come hither to me.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Here's one Mr. Crack enquires for you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: That's he—bring him in—

sp.speaker: Mr.
sp.p: Crack your Servant.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Your Servant Sir, your humble Servant, Madam.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Your Servant Sir, I am told you ha' been an Oxford Scholler.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: A Scholler Madam? a Schollers Egg—emptyed by old ſuck. Eggs, of all that Nature gave me, and crumbled full of Eſſences, Hypoſtaſes, and other ſtuff o' their baking.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Why did not you apply your ſelf to Divinity?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Leave Wenches for Pigs, Madam; 'tis true I may Wench then too, but it muſt be with Fear and Reverence, I hate that.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Why wou'd not you be a Phyſician?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: A Gold-finder Madam? look into Jakes for bits o' money? I had a Spirit above it. I had an ambition to be of ſome honourable profeſſion; ſuch as People of Quality undertake. As for inſtance, Pimping. A Pimp is as much above a Doctor, as a Cook is above a Scullion; when a Pimp has foul'd a Diſh, a Doctor ſcours it.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: This is an arch Blade.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Oh! you are pleas'd to ſay ſo, Madam; 'tis more your goodneſs than my deſert.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Well Mr. Crack, you know what you have undertaken.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: I'le do't—The Lady's yours.—Give me ſome Mony.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: There, there.—

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Gold! thou Son o' the Sun, and Brother o' the Stars, Nutmeg o' comfort, and Roſe o' delight, as my Friend the King o' Perſia call's himſelf,—what can'ſt thou not do great Prince, if I be thy chief Miniſter?—

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: This is a notable Fellow,—our next Plot muſt be to ſecure your Rival Sr. Courtly Nice.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Hang him, he ſecure's himſelf by his Foppery's, ſhe deſpiſes him.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Not many Lady's do ſo.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Oh! no, Madam, he's the General Guitarre o' the Town, inlay'd with every thing Women fancy; Gaytry, Gallantry, Delicacy, Nicety, Courteſy.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: And pray, put in Gold too.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: True Madam, Oh! the Ladies love to have him in their Chambers. and play themſelves a ſleep with him.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Well, I have provided one ſhall thrumble on him.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Oh! Fire and Water are not ſo contrary, Sr. Courtly is ſo civil a Creature, and ſo reſpectful to every thing belongs to a Gentleman, he ſtand's bare to his own Perewig. Surly uncovers to nothing but his own Nightcap, nor to that if he be drunk, for he ſleeps in his Hat. Sr. Courtly is ſo gentle a Creature, he writes a challenge in the ſtile of a Billet-doux. Surley talks to his Miſtreſs, as he wou'd to a Hector that wins his Mony. Sr. Courtly is ſo pleas'd with his own Perſon, his daily contemplation, nay his Salvation is a Lookinglaſs, for there he finds Eternal happyneſs. Surley's Heaven at leaſt, his Prieſt is his Claret Glaſs; for to that he confeſſes all his Sins, and from it receives Abſolution and Comfort. But his damnation is a Looking glaſs, for there he finds an Eternal fire in his Noſe. In ſhort if you wou'd make a Poſſet for the Devil, mingle theſe two, for there never was ſo ſweet a thing as Sr. Courtley, ſo ſower as Surley. But how will you get 'em together? for nothing has power over Surley, but Claret and the Devil.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Yes I have. Heaven is pleas'd to think the Devil himſelf has not miſchief enough to plague that ill-natur'd Rogue, and joyns me in Commiſſion with him to torment him with Love; he loves me.—

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Love? can he love?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: So much, he neglects his Claret for me; and comes hither hourly to perform his Devotions to me, but in ſuch a ſlovenly manner; 'tis ſuch a Non-Conformiſt to all decent Ceremonies.

sp.speaker: Surley within.
sp.p: Where's your Miſtreſs?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p:
I hear him, we'l ha' ſport with him. He abhors his Love worſe than
Murder or Treaſon, for thoſe are miſchiefs to others, but Love he accounts High-Treaſon againſt his own damnable Perſon; and he's more aſham'd of it, than he wou'd be of a Beaſts Taile if it grew out of him. Therefore I'le conceal, and do you charge him with it, you ſhall hear how he'l renounce it, then will I appear like Conſcience to a ſick debauch, and you ſhall ſee what an aukard Penitent I'le make him.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Honeſt Surly, how do'ſt do?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Prethee look in my Water.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: In thy Water?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Ay, for I don't love to anſwer impertinent queſtions,

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Is it impertinent to enquire after the health of a Friend?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: A Friend? thy talk is more boyiſh than thy Face. Do'ſt thou think there are ſuch Friends? thou believ'ſt there are Mair-maids and Centaures I warrant; for ſuch Friends. Monſters that grow to ſome other Beaſts, and are the leaſt part o' themſelves?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Why? haſt thou no concern for any Beaſts but thy ſelf?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Yes Bird, for many things for my own ſake; for Witty Men whil'ſt they drink with me, handſome Whores whil'ſt they lye with me, Dogs, Horſes or Cattle whil'ſt they belong to me; after that, I care not if the Wits behang'd, the Whores be pox'd, and all the Cattle bewitch'd.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: A very generous temper.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: 'Tis a wiſe and honeſt temper. The pretended good nature is ill nature; it makes a Man an Aſs to others he bears their Burden, a Rogue to himſelf, he cheats himſelf of his quiet and Fortune. I am ſo very honeſt to my ſelf, if the whole World were hang'd it ſhou'd not rob me of a Minutes eaſe, I thank Heaven for it.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Was ever ſuch a Barbarian?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Thou 'rt an Aſs; which is the Barbarian, he that eats Man, or the Man that's eaten? The Rogue that grieves away my Fleſh eats me, and is a Barbarian; ſo is he that with vexation gnawes himſelf; I am no ſuch Cannibal.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Haſt thou no compaſſion?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: I know not what it is.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Suppoſe you ſee a Man o' Quality in miſery.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Let him be in miſery and be damn'd.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Are you not concern'd for his Quality?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: The leſs for that, becauſe if he fancies the whimſey he has it to pleaſe him.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: To trouble him.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Then to comfort him I'le tell him he's the Son of a Whore, and his Grandfather roſe by Pimping.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Suppoſe you ſaw a Man o' parts unfortunate?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Let his parts look after him.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: They'l afflict him.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Then to quiet him I'le tell him he's an Aſs.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Have you no charity? do you never give any thing to the Poor?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: As much as any Man.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Nothing.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Does no Man give any thing?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Not to the Poor; they give it to themſelves; ſome Fools have Diſeaſes in their Natures, they never ſee any one in pain, but they feel half on't, and ſo they give money to eaſe themſelves.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Ha' you no love for any thing?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: I have Appetite.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Have you no love for Women?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: I ha' Luſt.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: No Love?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: That's the ſame thing, the word Love is a Fig-Leaf to cover the naked ſence, a faſhion brought up by Eve, the Mother of Jilts, ſhe Cuckolded her Husband with the Serpent then pretendedto modeſty and fell a making Plackets preſently. And her Daughters take up the Trade, you may import what Lewdneſs you will into their Common-wealth, if you will waſh it over with ſome fine Nmae. You may proclaime at Mercat-croſs, how great an Adorer you are of ſuch a Womans Charms? how much you deſire to be admitted into her Service; that is, how luſty a Centaur you are, that the Horſe in you is much the major part, and ſhe ſhall receive all this without a bluſh, whil'ſt the Beaſt trots to her under the Name of a Lover; when if ſhe had any Wit ſhe'd know, a Lover is a more impudent Name than Whoremaſter; for a Whoremaſter throws all his Bombes at a whole City, your Lover waſts all his upon a ſingle Houſe. That when a Woman deſires a Lover, ſhe deſires to have the whole Brute to her ſelf.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: What do you laugh at Sir?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Only that your Miſtreſs has heard your learned Diſcourſes Sir. Pray appear Madam, and own you have loſt your Wager, is he a Lover or no?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Here's a young Treacherous Rogue.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Yes—a Brutal one—are theſe your Sentiments of Love Sir? was it this you meant when you talk'd of Love? when we grow Lovers do we degenerate into Brutes? I thought there was a generous Paſſion, of which a Beaſt cou'd have no more ſence, than he has of Muſick or Poetry. And to ſuch Love you pretended Sir.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: I'le whedle her, (aſideto Fa.) So I do ſtill Madam, but why muſt I let a Boy Catechiſe me? I have that Muſical, Poetical, Fantaſtical love, you ſpeak of, and a pox on me for it; you'l neither be my Slipper, nor my Shooe, my Wench to ſlip on and of at pleaſure, nor my Wife, that is a Whore buckled on.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: You are charming in your expreſſions.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Mr. Surly, Madam, is a miſtical peice, to be underſtood like a Prophecy, where Rams and He-Goats ſtand for Kings and Princes. Mr. Surly's, rank expreſſions muſt ſignifie Virtue and Honour.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: No, no, they ſignifie his own filthy meaning; and the truth is, love has no other ſence, in this corrupt Age. Now if a Woman by bluſhes or otherwiſe, confeſſes ſhe thinks a Man, a fine Gentleman, he to requite her ſends her preſently a Libel call'd a Billet-doux, where he in fine words tells her to her Face, he thinks her a Wench, and invites her to lye with him. This ruins all Converſation, Men are always driving their brutal appetites to the Plays, the Court, to Church, like Drovers their Beaſts to every Market; and there's no converſing with 'em, unleſs you'l take their Cattel of their hands.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Madam, I love your in your own faſhion, admire you, adore you, and the Devil and all, what wou'd you have?—Now will this ſimple Jade believe me?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: He calls you ſimple Jade, Madam, and ſay's you'l believe him.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: You Malapert Boy, why do you meddle in my buſineſs?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: 'Tis my buſineſs, ſhe's my Friend, and I wont ſee her abus'd.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: A Friend to the Woman loves your Enemy, Tom-Fool?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: No, ſhe hates him, and has quarrel'd with him, and I wou'd ha' had you ſtep into his room.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Oh! ho!

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Now who's the Tom-Fool?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: I am, look you Madam, that Rogue deſpayr made me talk like an Aſs, and I am ſorry for it.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I know you are Sir, I know your baſe deſire is for your puniſhment; confin'd to my Eyes, and I'le uſe you as you deſerve.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Come, Madam, let me interpoſe; though you will not receive Mr. Surly as a half Horſe, you may as a whole Aſs, a Drudge, you know you have buſineſs moſt agreeable to his ill Nature, pray employ him.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Well; I'le make tryal of him, you pretend you love me Generouſly.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Yes, and Damnably.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Know then my Lord Belguard, is (as I have of late perceiv'd) ſunk with the reſt of the Age, into baſe opinions of Love and Women, that I am angry I ever had a good thought of him.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Look upon his addreſs to me, as an affront, and will revenge it.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Better and better.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: And you ſhall do it.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Beſt of all.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Do not you know Sir Courtly Nice?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: That you ſhou'd joyn knowledge with ſuch a Fop? 'tis a queſtion to be put to a Boy? I may know Philoſophy, but to ask a Man if he knows a Horn-Book? for ſuch a thing is this Fop; guilded on the out ſide, on the inſide, the Criſs Croſs row, and always hanging at the Girdle of a Girl.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: You have deſcrib'd him right. This rop has my Lord Belguard entie'd to accept his Siſter with no Fortune, but her Birth and Beauty. Now if you'l break the Match, you'l be to me the moſt annable Creature in the World.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Or the moſt damnable, if you Jilt me.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: In earneſt of a farther favour here's my hand.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: There's the Devil in it. Tis transforming my ſhape, I am growing a Womans Aſs, I feel the Ears prick out o' my ſkin already; and I muſt hoof it away with her load of Folly upon my back. Well I am thy Aſs at preſent, but if thou Jilts me, I will be thy Devil.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: 'Tis the fitteſt Office for thee; thou art ſo like one already, you may paſs for Twins. Now Mr. Farewel let's go in and Laugh.
sp.stage: Scene Lord Belguards Houſe. Enter Hot-head and Teſtimony.

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: He ſhall not ſpeak with her, I dont approve of it.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: You approve Sirrah? what ha' you to do?

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: I have Authority.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: You Authority?

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: Yes, from my Lord.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: You had it then out of his Kitchin, Sirrah; the Beef o' the Nation breeds all the Maggots in the Peoples heads. I am ſometimes tempted to throw down their Porridge-pots, and ſpill the Divine Right of Presbitery. In ſhort my Lord is a man of honour, and you have belyed him, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: It is well known I make a Conſcience.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Ay, you Rogues making o' Conſciences is a great trade among your Party, and you deſerve to looſe your Ears for it.

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: I mean I keep a Conſcience.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Y'ave reaſon Sirrah, it keeps you; but that an honeſt Lord ſhou'd give money for a Rogues falſe Conſcience.—Oones!—

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: Well but dont ſwear.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Sirrah, who ſwears?

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: Dee hear?—don't ſwear I ſay.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Oones! Sirrah, don't preach to me.

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: Don't ſwear then.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Sirrah, if you preach to me, I'le cut your Pate.

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: Had I a Sword 'twere more than you cou'd do.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: How now Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: Nay but don't throttle me, don't Godfrey me.

sp.speaker: Aunt.
sp.p: What's the noyſe? what's the rudeneſs, Couſin Hot-head? you a Gentleman, and make a Bear-Garden of a Perſons of Honours houſe?

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Better make a Bear-garden of it than a Conventicle; here's a Fanatick Rogue ordain'd ruling elder o'th' Family by my Lord, as the Rogue ſays, ſo he undertakes to govern and Preach.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: And you undertake to Govern and correct? Couſin no body Governs here but I; if he had committed faults, you ſhou'd have brought him before me.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Oh! you'd have him enter'd in your Office?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p:
What do you mean? obſcenely? you are confident You are the firſt
Gentleman that offer'd to ſay a wanton thing to me.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: To your great ſorrow.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: What's the quarrel here?

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: There's a Taylor wou'd fain ſpeak with you.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: All this noyſe to introduce a Taylor?

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: He can't get through this Fellows narrow Conſcience, yet there is room for a whole Common-wealth.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Call in the Taylor; there muſt no Cloaths be made without my orders, that I may ſee 'em modeſt.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: A Taylor? I order'd no Taylor.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: How now, Sir? what are you?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: A Taylor, Madam.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Who ſent you? I know you not.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Your own Taylor, Mr. Stitch, Madam.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: How chance he came not himſelf?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: He's ſick, Madam.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: And can you work well, for we are very hard to pleaſe? There's ſcarce a Taylor in Town can make me endure to ſee my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: The fault lyes in—Fifty—Fifty—.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Indeed Madam, I muſt needs ſay my Country men are not the beſt Taylors in the World. This is a fine Nation, and all ſpoyl'd by the Taylors. Heaven makes the Women Angels, and Taylors make 'em Hedg-hogs; 'tis a ſad ſight to ſee 'em, now I'le make an Angel of a crooked Pin.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Ay, where did you learn your Skill?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: In France, Madam.

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: In France? then Friend I believe you are a Papiſt.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Sirrah, I believe you are a Presbyterian.

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: Friend, if you be a Papiſt I'le ha' you before a Juſtice.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Sirrah, if you be a Presbyterian, I'le kick you down Stairs.

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: What are you Friend?

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Ay, what are you Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: What am I? why, I'm a Taylor, I think the Men are mad.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Intolerable; Mr. Teſtimony pray leave us, and Couſin Hot-head, I ſhall deſire the ſame of you, unleſs you'l behave your ſelf like a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: I will behave my ſelf like a Gentleman, for I'le know of my Lord when he comes home, if he has given this Rogue Authority over me; if he has I'le demand Satisfaction of him; if he be innocent woe be to your prickears, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: I fear you not.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Mr. Teſtimony, I once more deſire you'l give us liberty.

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p:
Yes, Forſooth, I dare truſt the young Gentlewoman with you, Forſooth
—you are a grave—Gentlewoman and in years—Forſooth.—

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: In years, rude Clown.—

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: And truly ſhe's a very pretty ſweet Woman, and deſerves to have great care taken of her.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Well Sir, we'l excuſe the care at this time.—

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: Pretty Woman.—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Pray leave us—.

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: Sweet Woman—I profeſs ſhe's ſtrangely alluring, I had beſt retire leaſt I fall into frailty, and be diſcovered.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Now, Madam, before I take meaſure of you, I'l ſhew you ſome Patterns—pleaſe you to look upon ſome Madam, you have judgment—.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Let me ſee.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: To you, Madam, I wou'd recommend this peice.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Mr. Farewel's Picture? oh! I Sirrah! now I gueſs thee—my Dear—Dear—

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Have a care o' your Aunt Madam.—I have a Letter too.—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Give it me—quick—quick—

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Theſe are pretty Silks.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: The beſt in France, Mdaam.
Where's my Siſter?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: My Brother? I hope he does not know thee.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: No, if he does I'm a dead Man.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Haſt thou no diſguiſe for fear he ſhou'd?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Only this great pair of Spectacles.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What Fellow's this?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: A Taylor.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Not your Taylor?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: No, he's ſick and ſent this Fellow in his Room.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: How comes ſuch a young Fellow to wear Spectacles?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Young my Lord? I'm above Five and Fifty.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Thou bear'ſt thy age well.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Ay, every where but in my Eyes I thank Heaven.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: This Fellow may be a Bawd for ought I know, I'le watch him.
sp.stage: Aunt views the Patterns, Bell. ſtands behind his Siſter, and watches Cr. Cr. mean while puts his Meaſure before, and delivers her a Letter.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Well, Madam, I perceive your Ladyſhip likes the Pattern I ſhew'd you firſt.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I have ſeen the whole piece.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: And your Ladyſhip likes it?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Oh! very well.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: I'le aſſure you, Madam, you'l like it mightily when 'tis upon you, and you have a ſweet body to work for. I do not doubt, Madam, but to get a great deal o' credit and a great deal o' Cuſtome by you, among the Ladies, as ſoon as ever they ſee my work.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Well let's ſee your work, and I'le ſay ſomething.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: That you ſhall and ſpeedily, Madam, I'le bring you home as ſweet a peice o' Work, as ever you had in your Life. You'l look upon the Pattern I ſhew'd you laſt?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: That's for the inſide; do you like much Bombaſt, Madam?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: No—.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Well, Madam—I ha' taken a Surveigh o' your fine Body—now you ſhall be pleas'd according to your own hearts deſire—your Servant Madam—.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Well Siſter—prepare to receive a Viſit from Sr. Courtly Nice, this Afternoon.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Oh! dear! then I muſt dreſs. He's a great Critick.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: She deſigns him for her ſelf, wou'd ſhe cou'd get him.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Sr. Courtly and I have agreed; pray give him your promiſe.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: So ſoon? 'twill be fulſome, he's abſtemious.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Therefore take him whil'ſt he has an edge.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: You uſe to deſpiſe Fools, how chance you marry amongſt 'em?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Becauſe none but Fools will marry. Wits are but few and commonly poor; Fools are numerous and rich. Fortune is as fond of thoſe bits of Men, as Bigots are of Reliques; wraps 'em in Silver.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Better they were buryed. A Fool in a Coach is like a Knave in a Pillory, the Object of publick deriſion.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Oh! there are few to deride 'em, many to admire 'em, ſo many, I have oft admired how one Apple,
sp.l: Shou'd ſuch Diſeaſes in old Adam breed.

l.hi: That from his Loyns not Men, but Wroms proceed.

div.head: ACT. III.
div.stage: Scene, Covent-Garden-Square. Enter Farewel and Crack meeting.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Oh! the News! the News! art thou an Angel or a Devil? bring'ſt thou Joys or Torments?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Joys! joys! joys!

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Angel! Angel! Angel!

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: In the firſt place I deliver'd your Picture.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Rare.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: And ſhe kiſſed it.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: kiſſed it?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Sweetly, wantonly, laſciviouſly. She ſet me ſo on fire, I kiſs'd all the Wenches as I came along, and made their moyſt lips fiz again.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Oh! Rogue! Rogue! delicious Rogue.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Then I deliver'd the Letter, and before her Brothers face.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Before his face? ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Prepare this Night to be the happyeſt o' Mortals. Give me ſome more Mony.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Mony? I'le ſell my Land rather than thou ſhalt want. That one Inheritance will purchaſe me two, one in Love, and another in laughing at this politick Brother.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: No, no, Inheritances as for laughing, I believe you will have an Anuity for life; but for Love you'l only have a leaſe for three or four Years.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Pleaſant Rogue! here's Money.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: So, ſo, I wiſh you joy I wiſh you joy.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: See Surly going to my Rival; my affair thrives admirably.
sp.stage: Enter Surly. Knocks, enter a Servant.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Is Nice within?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Nice Sir?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Ay, Nice Sir; is not your Maſters name Nice.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: 'Tis Sir Courtly Nice.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Well Sir, if I have a mind to clip half his Name, 'tis not Treaſon, is it Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: I believe not Sir.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Then get you in, and tell your Maſter I'd ſpeak with him

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: What ſort o' domineering Man is this?
sp.stage: Scene, a Chamber—Sir Courly Nice dreſſing, Men and Women ſinging to him.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Very fine! extreamly fine. Gentlemen and Ladies, will you do me the favour to walk in, and accept of a ſmall Collation? I am in ſome haſt to dreſs upon an extraordinary occaſion. You'l Pardon me?—your very humble Servant—.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Very fine.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: You Sot, 'twas very barbarous.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Your honour ſaid 'twas very fine.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: You Clown, don't you know what belongs to a Gentleman? Complaiſance is the very thing of a Gentleman, The thing that ſhew's a Gentleman. Wherever I go, all the World cryes that's a Gentleman, my life on't a Gentleman; and when y'ave ſaid a Gentleman, you have ſaid all.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Is there nothing elſe Sr. belongs to a Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Yes, Bon mine, fine Hands, a Mouth well furniſh'd—

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: With fine Language—.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Fine Teeth you ſot; fine Language belongs to Pedants and poor Fellows that live by their Wits. Men of Quality are above Wit. 'Tis true for our diverſion ſometimes we write, but we ne'r regard Wit. I write but I never writ any Wit.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: How then Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: I write like a Gentleman, ſoft and eaſie.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Does your Honour write any Plays?

sp.speaker: Sir. Co.
sp.p: No, that's Mechanick, I beſtow ſome Garniture on Plays, as a Song or a Prologue.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Then your Honour is only a Haberdaſher o' ſmall Wares?

sp.speaker: Sir. Co.
sp.p: A Haberdaſher, you ſawcy Raſcal?

sp.speaker: 2. Ser.
sp.p: Here's one Mr. Surly to viſit your Honour.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Surly, what the Devil brings him hither?

sp.speaker: 2. Ser.
sp.p: He has been walking about the Rooms this quarter of an hour, and wou'd not let me bring him in, till he had fould 'em all with his dirty Shoes.

sp.speaker: Sir. Co.
sp.p: A Nauſeous, Beaſtly, Sloven, Clown, Fool, Sot.

sp.speaker: Dear Mr.
sp.p: Surly your moſt humble Servant. (Sir Co. Bows to receive him.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: What, are you unbu—buckling my Shooe?

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Dear Mr. Surly—he ſtinks horribly— aſide.) How came I to enjoy—a very Polecat— aſide.) This great happyneſs?—pox! foh! you and I have been aſide.) long piquee, and I'm amaz'd to ſee you at my levee.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: I begin to think, thou art a good honeſt Fellow, and have a mind we ſhou'd no longer be two lo—lo—Loggerheads, but one.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Dear Sir, you are always ſo divertiſing; Well Sir, ſhall I beg a favour of you?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Leave to dreſs before you, Sir. I am to meet ſome fine Women to day, one preſently.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Prethee dreſs, and be damnd—ſhall we di—dine together?

sp.speaker: Sir. Co.
sp.p: Yes Sir, I ſuppoſe, and Sup too—.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: That's kind, well when?

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: About Five o' clock Sir.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: In the Kings Box, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Muſt you and I, dine in the Kings Box?

sp.speaker: Sir. Co.
sp.p: Oh! deareſt! I beg your Pardon Ten thouſand times, I thought you ask'd me where I ſhou'd meet the Lady.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Pox o' the Lady; I ask where we ſhall Dine?

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Really Sir I don't know, I can't put my head into one o' your beaſtly eating houſes, nor ſwallow the filthy meat you eat there, if you'd give me One hundred pound.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Filthy Meat? Sir I eat as good Meat as you do.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! dear Mr. Surly, no doubt the meat in its own nature may be very innocent; but when once it has committed familiarity with the beaſtly Fiſts of Cooks and Butchers, 'tis to me an unpardonable Sinner. My Butcher cuts up all his Meat with a Fork.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Does he cut up an Ox with a Fork?

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Ay, and he cuts up an Ox as neatly as a Lady does a Partridge.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Well, then I'le accept o' thy Dinner.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Dear Sir, your moſt humble Servant; pox on him (aſide) I wiſh I be capable o' the great happyneſs. For I came but laſt Night from my Country houſe, and I queſtion whether I have all things in order or no, Whoſe there? are all things brought from my Country houſe?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: No Sir, your Butler has forgot your Salt.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Left my Salt? careleſs Raſcal. Let him take Horſe immediately.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Sir he's rid poſt for it.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Rid poſt for Salt? whether?

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: To my Country houſe.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: How far's that off?

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: But a little way, not above Forty miles.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Send Forty miles out o' London for Salt? Is there not Salt enough in London for you?

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Ay, ſtuff pawm'd by Butlers and Waiters, they take up the Wenches coats, then handle the Salt.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Here's a Rogue— (aſide) well come let's drink a Glaſs o' Wine then.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p:
Oh! dear Mr. Surly, if you name Wine, you make me throw up my Soul. I have abhor'd Wine ever ſince I was in France, and ſaw what
barbarous Education they give that generous Creature. Duce take me, Sir, if the Clowns don't preſs all the Grapes with their filthy naked Feet. Oh! beaſtly naſty Dogs! no wonder we are poyſon'd with their Wine.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Prethee what o' that? the Wine purges before it comes over.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! Lord Mr. Surly what a Phraſe is there? you'l Pardon my Freedom, Sir?—

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Moſt civil Coxcomb (aſide) well what muſt we drink for drink I muſt?

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: I have ſeveral drinks of my own compoſing at your Service, as Mead, Syder, Ale.—

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Ale? there's Sauce for a Woodcock. Come let's taſt a Bottle.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Fetch a Bottle; This Fellow will Poyſon me—.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Well I come to requeſt a favour o' thee.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Your moſt humble Servant Sir, how de'e' like this Cravat?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: What's that to my buſineſs? I come to make a requeſt to thee.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: 'Tis well tyed too, with a great deal o'humour.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: A Pox on thee, mind me.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Your moſt humble Servant Sir.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: I am going to make Love.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Before you drink Sir?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Before I drink Sir—.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Well Sir, ſince you'l have it ſo, I'le wait on you down ſtairs.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Is the Devil in the Fellow? I tell thee I'm going to make love.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! Lord Sir, I beg your pardon a thouſand times.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: And I come to beg thy aſſiſtance.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! dear Sir.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: For thou haſt a knack on't. Thou art the only Court Card Women love to play with; the very Pam at Lantereloo, the Knave that picks up all.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! Sir, you are ſo obliging;—and ſtinking—Pox take him.—

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: And 'tis a very pretty Woman I'm in love with; my Lord Belguard's Siſter Leonora; thou know'ſt her.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: The Rogue's my Rival, he was born for my confuſion (aſide.) Ay, Sir, I have the honour of ſome ſmall acquaintance there.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Prethee ſpeak for me.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! dear Sir, you have a great Talent of your own:

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: But thine's a better. One thing I am ſure thou may'ſt do, there's an abominable Fop makes Love to her, and I am told is to marry her; prethee tell him he's a Son of a Whore.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Really Sir I'm unfortunate; I ha' no manner o' Genius to that ſort o' Converſation.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Say my words. Tell him if he proceeds, I'le not only Libel him, but tweag him by the Noſe, Kick him, Cudgel him, and run him through the Guts. Prethee tell him this.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! pray Sir give me Ayr.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Prethee do.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Sir I am ready to—

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: And thou wilt tell the Puppy this?

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: I will upon my Soul.
sp.stage: Enter a Servant with Wine and Glaſſes.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Then thou art an honeſt Fellow—ſo, is the drink come? fill a Glaſs, why two Glaſſes? do you think I cannot drink after your Maſter?

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Pox o' your Complyment—.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Here Nice, my Miſtreſſes health.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: What miſery is this Beaſt impoſing on me? he coughs in the Glaſs too—

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Pox on't, a whole gulp went the wrong way, come off with it 'Tis my Miſtreſſes health.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: This Fellows the Devil—

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Off with it, Man.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: I never was ſo embaraſs'd ſince I was born.—

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Oones! off with it.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: I muſt take the beaſtly portion down, but I ſhall be moſt horrible ſick after it.—

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: So, now thou art an honeſt Fellow, now I'le kiſs thee.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: The Devil thou wilt? more miſeries? (aſide.) nay but Mr. Surly.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: I ſwear I will.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Nay but you'l diſorder me.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: I ſwear I will.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: But Sir I'm going upon your occaſions to your Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Nay then I'le give thee two kiſſes, one for thy ſelf and another for her.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! Hell. (aſide) nay but Mr. Surly.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: I ſwear I will.
This Bottle Beer is damn'd windy—well honeſt Nice farewell to thee.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Who's there? I'm ſick to death,—to death!—lead me in—get my bed ready—and a Bath—and ſome Perfumes—I'm ſick to death,—I'm dead.
sp.stage: Scene Lord Belguard's Houſe. Enter Bell. with Farewel's Picture in his hand.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Thou horrid Viſion! wou'd I had met with the worſt Fiend in Hell, rather than thee; in thee there is a Legion exciting me to Blood—blood—Who's there?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: My Lord—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: My Coach—to blood—blood—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: To Blood? what means my Brother?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Be gone:

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: To whom do you ſpeak?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Bleſs us; Nephew what ailes you?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Alas my Lord, I fear you are a going to quarrel.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Yes, I'm going to puniſh one who Violates my Fathers, my Will and calls my Mother Whore.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: What execrable Wretch is that?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Thy ſelf.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Me?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Yes, what doſt thou elſe but proclaim our Mother falſe, when ſhe conceiv'd a thing ſo oppoſite to all our Fathers race as thou art?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: In what?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: In Infamy; when was there a ſpot in our name, till Heaven for our ſins ſent thee among us? and I am going to deſtroy thee in thy lewd undoer

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I know of no reproach in our Family but your madneſs, deſtroy that. What are your Spyes and Coxcombs, but ſo many Capital Letters, wherein you write over your Door, My Siſter is a wanton Woman.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: 'Tis truth, you are not only a wanton, but a wicked Woman; not only Intrigue, but with the Enemy of our Family, Farewel.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I am betray'd—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Do you bluſh?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: At your Folly.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Dare you deny it?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Who dare accuſe me?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: This Picture, which I found in your Chamber.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Horrid Creature!—I ſhall ſwoon away.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: How ſhall I bring off this (aſide) All this noiſe for a Picture? if you had found a little humane Effigies in ſwadling Clouts, there might ha' been ſome ſquawling.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Do you laugh at your ſhame?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: She ſhall ha' no cauſe.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Do, kill me, before you know whether he's guilty or no.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I'le know it from himſelf. If he denys it, it will be ſome revenge to make him ſtab his Soul with Lyes. He ſhall ſwear not only that he never did, but never will ſend ſo much as an Imagination to you.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Do, if you wou'd force him hither, what charm to a Man of ſpirit, like daring?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: She ſpeaks ſence in that.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: If you wou'd be fighting, fight your own jealouſie, which abuſes you worſe than Mr. Farewel can do, my Honour protects you from him; but neither Wit or Honour, can guard you from the rude inſolence of your jealouſie, which is now ſending you of an Errant, a Footman o' Spirit wou'd ſcorn, to proclaim the diſhonour of your own Siſter. Fye! Fye!

sp.speaker: Bell,
sp.p: And ſo I muſt ſit down tamely with this abuſe?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: You are not abus'd, the Picture was found at Church.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: At Church? do you intrigue at Church?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: They do nothing elſe, the Church is almoſt as bad as the Porch.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Nay there's ſhameful doings, that's the truth on't, it provokes my Fleſh to ſee how the young Men fling their Eyes about.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: And not upon her.—

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: But 'tis no marvail; when Women will encourage 'em. No Fellows dare gape upon me, becauſe I never encourage Fellows.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: A Face of Fifty is ſmall encouragement.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Nay no wonder the Devils cauſe thrives, he has a numerous Clergy, Heaven has but one Miniſter in the Church, and whil'ſt he is Preaching Divinity, the Devil has a thouſand of both Sexes, by all the Oratory of looks and dreſſes, preaching Fornication and Adultery.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Too true, well ſhe's certainly undone. I dare not examine her Breaſts, if there ſhou'd be any thing in 'em, I ſhou'd dye.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: In my breaſts?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Ay, Gentlewoman, do you think I regard your Flim flam ſtory o'the Church?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: 'Tis not my ſtory, my Woman found it in Weſtminſter Abby, at Prayers, and I knowing what work wou'd be made with it, commanded her to burn it, and ſhe has dar'd to diſſobey me.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: Indeed, Madam, I thought to have preſented it to a Friend o' mine; and laying it out o' my hand unfortunately in your Honours Chamber, my Lord found it.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Oh! how nimbly ſhe takes the lye at the firſt rebound?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Out upon you; I'm extream ſick—lead me in—not you—you are not fit to touch a Woman o' my Virtue. Theſe things have ſtrange impreſſion upon me.—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: That you don't ſhare in 'em—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Pray, Siſter, go out o' my ſight, you are an horrour to me.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Your own Dreams are. Y'are as mad as a Prophet, you have always before your Eyes a Viſion of Horns and Whores.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: All this goes upon the ſcore of Farewel's heart blood if he be guilty, I'le make enquiry preſently, and ſearch at what gap this Treachery entred.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Oh! unfortunate negligence!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Who's there, Couſin Hot head, Teſtimony?

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Oh! are you here?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ay, to your ſorrow, if you have play'd me falſe.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: You ha' ſerv'd me finely.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Do you firſt complain?

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Coupled me with a Dog?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: But you ha' Coupled my Siſter Sir.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: With a Fanatick Rogue.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: No—with a finer Gentleman. Who brought this Picture?

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: The common Fire-fork of Rebellion.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: A Fire-fork.—Fork me no Forks—Who brought this Picture?

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: The rotten rump ſhou'd ha' been burnt—when 'twas only Roaſted.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: The rotten Rump—Anſwer me, or i'le fight thee.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Anſwer you what?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Who brought this Picture? I found it in my Siſter's Chamber.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Then your Fanatick Rogue conveigh'd it thither to make me ſuſpected, out of his malice to the Common-Prayer. I'le cut the Rogue to peices.
sp.stage: Enter Teſtimony with a great Sword by his ſide.

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: I am here.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: How now, Sworded?

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: To preſerve my Life. My life is threatned by that bloody Papiſt.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: How, Sirrah? dare you think of fighting me?

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: Yes, and hope to do it, through Providence.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Drawing before me?

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Will you protect a Fanatick? I ſee what you are.
Well Sirrah, though I may not cut your Throat, i'le choak you Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: De'e, hear the bloody Papiſt? He'l throttle me.

sp.speaker: Hot.
