sp.p: Sirrah, i'le cram the Oaths of Allegiance, and Supremacy into you, and they'l ſtick in your Throat, though Treaſon wont, and ſo i'le to a Juſtice preſently.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And ſtay with him, and never plague me more. Now Sir do you reſolve my queſtion.

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: I do reſolve I will not take the Oaths.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I do not ask you about the Oaths.

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: Why, if you ask me Ten thouſand times, I will not take the Oaths.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Did one ever ſee ſuch a Coxcomb?

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: Call me what you pleaſe, I will not take the Oaths—So do your worſt.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: A very fine account of my buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: My Lord a Gentleman deſires to ſpeak with your Honour.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I'm not to be ſpoke with, i'm a broad—my Soul is—in the heart of Farewel, ripping it up for this Secret. What Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: One from th' Eaſt-Indies, My Lord, he brings a Letter from your Uncle Rich.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: He comes in a Storm; he will find worſe Weather here, than any he met at Sea. But i'le endeavour to compoſe my ſelf—admit him—
sp.stage: Enter a Man dreſt like a Merchant.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: My Lord, your Lordſhips moſt humble Servant. I perceive your Lordſhip has forgot me; you will know me better, when I acquaint you, who I am. My Father had the honour of being a Retainer to your Lordſhips Father, of Honourable memory; and ſent me ſome Years ſince to the Eaſt Indies, in the Service of your Noble Uncle, Mr. Rich. My name is Waytewel.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Oh! Mr. Waytewel, I am glad to ſee you, truly you are ſo chang'd, if you had not told me who you was, I ſhou'd never ha' known you.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I believe ſo my Lord—for I'm ſure you never ſaw my Face before, but the Picture of it you have—for Waytewel was my Picture. (aſide) Time and Travels will alter a Man, but truly I have loſt nothing by my Travels but my Countenance; and in the room have gotten what's better, a convenient ſmall competency of ſome Seven or Eight thouſand pound; Heaven and your Uncles love be prais'd. I have brought Your Lordſhip ſome Letters from your Noble Uncle, and a ſmall Preſent of ſome Threeſcore thouſand pound.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Only the trouble of it, my Lord. Your Uncle contracted in th' Indies an intimate Friendſhip with Sir Nicholas Calico, Preſident for the Eaſt India Company. Sir Nicholas dyed, and left moſt part of his Eſtate (which was near a Hundred thouſand pound,) to his only Son, Sir Thomas. But poor Sir Thomas happen'd in his Fathers Life time to fall into a Diſtemper, which gave him a ſcurvy flaw in his Brain, that Sir Nicholas left him and all his Eſtate to your Uncles Guardianſhip. Now your Noble Uncle perceiving his affairs are like to detain him many Years in th' Indies, and fearing if he ſhou'd dye, poor Sir Thomas might be cheated of all; he has like a Worthy and honeſt Gentleman, ſent Sir Thomas and all his Eſtate to your Lordſhips care, as theſe Letters will teſtifie. I ſuppoſe your Lordſhip is well acquainted with your Uncles Hand and Seal.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I am, and this is his Hand and Seal reads—um—um—um—to preſerve him from being cheated here, or beg'd in England, I take the boldneſs to recommend him, to the care of ſo Noble a Perſon as your Lordſhip—um—um—um—. Well Sir the Letter expreſſes what you told me.—Where is the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I brought him along with me; he's in the next room, my Lord. Poor Gentleman, he has the oddeſt Phraſes and ways with him. He will needs be attended like a great Indian Mandarine, or Lord. And has brought with him ſeveral Siamites and Bantammers, that ſerve him as his Slaves, in the ridiculous Dreſſes and Modes of their own Countries. we had ſuch a gaping Rabble after us, as we came along.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Pray call him in, I long to ſee him—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: —Sir Thomas—pray come to my Lord.
sp.stage: Enter Crack ridiculouſly dreſt, attended by Men, in the Habits of Siamites, and Bantammers.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Which is the Peer?

sp.speaker: Man,
sp.p: This is my Lord.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Great Peer, your extream humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Your Servant Sir, you are recommended to me, by my Uncle.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: I know it my Lord, and am moſt incomparably oblig'd to him—. He is a Perſon, my Lord, that as to the altitudes of Friendſhip, and the moſt glorious Circumſtances of a Singular Perſon, is not to be caſt up by the Logarithmes of Oratory, nor his Latitude to be taken by the quadrangle of Circumlocution.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: So—I find I ſhall ha' ſtore o' Non-ſence.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: My Lord, I'm a Perſon that as to the Circumſtances of Mony, am not indifferently contemptible; and as to the circumſtances of Honour, I am by profeſſion a Merchant, by Generation a Knight. Sir Nicholas Calico applying his Perſon to my Mother, was the Author of, Sir, Your humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: So the Letter ſays.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: The Letter contains Verity.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Pox I ſhall be teaz'd.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: One thing more Sir, I am a Perſon that as to underſtadning, am under the circumſtances of Witchcraft. I lov'd in th' Indies, a fair Chriſtian Curioſity, and a nauſeous Indian Baggage, had a mind to apply to my Perſon her Tawny Circumſtances; and finding ſhe cou'd not obtain her Ambition, applys her ſelf to an Indian Bawd, and Bewitches me.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Pſhaw! Bewitch! what ſtuffs here?—

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Bewitches me Sir, what follow's thereupon? a loathing in me of Females? I abhor Women; fall into Agonys when I ſee Women. Pray let me ſee no Women.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You ſhall not Sir.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Pray My Lord, no Women.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I'le warrant you Sir.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: But as much Supper as you pleaſe, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You ſhall Sir.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: You are highly civiliz'd.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I told Your Honour he had ſuch odd ways; well My Lord, as ſoon as the Ship is come up the River, which will be in few days, I'le bring the Captain to wait upon Your Lordſhip, with the account of Sir Thomas his Eſtate, Aboard; which will amount to Forty thouſand pound, beſides Ten thouſand pound he has brought a ſhore in rough Diamonds. So, My Lord, your very humble Servant. Sir Thomas your Servant I leave you in good hands.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Your Servant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I'le order things for you. I muſt diſpoſe this Man quickly, for i'm horribly weary of him, and alſo impatient to go about my Affairs.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: 'Tis he—I'm ſure 'tis he—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: How now Siſter? what's your buſineſs here?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Staring at this ſtrange ſort o' Man.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You were no Woman elſe—pray get from him ſpeedily.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: You are not jealous of a Mad-man ſure? he's mad is he not?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Yes, and impertinently brings me vexation too from the Indies, at a time when I've enough at home, as every Man has, that keeps a Woman. Pray get from him, he hates to ſee Women.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Hates to ſee Women? ha! ha! Sir Thomas Calico your humble Servant, you are welcome from the Indies; but have a care of being diſcover'd, leaſt you be under the circumſtances of a Cudgel.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Truly Madam, I expect to have ſomething ſtick by my ribs preſently, that is to ſay a good Supper; which I have order'd. My Lord and I will ſup together, and you and Mr. Farewel.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: We ſup together? where? in the Grave? a fatall accident has' hapned, will bring us both thither. My Brother has found Mr. Farewel's Picture in my Chamber.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: He ſhall not keep it, he ſhall deliver both Picture and jealouſie.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Then thou art a Maſter. I told him my Woman found it in Weſtminſter-Abby; may be thou may'ſt make ſomething out o' that?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Stay let me conſider Weſtminſter-Abby, or the Abby of Weſtminſter—um—um—Let me alone—begone—he comes.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Come Sir, let me wait on you to your Chamber.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Hold, my Lord, a word, I have buſineſs of great conſequence, I muſt humbly apply to your underſtanding.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: So, I muſt be hindred with more Non-ſence.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: I've in the Indies, a delicate peice of my Fathers Rib, I beg your Lordſhip to adviſe me in the diſpoſal.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Oh! diſpoſe it how you pleaſe, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: 'Tis a Siſter I mean, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Oh! that's ſomething.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: She's ſweet and ſlender as a Clove, and is worth two Millions o' Coxcombs—Three hundred of 'em comes to Three Farthings; 'tis a Chineſe Mony. This Mony makes her much ſought in Marriage: The great Hobbommoccoes o' the Indies come gallopping upon Elephants, Camels, Rhinoceroſes, and Oxen to ſee her. Now my Father was under the circumſtances of great obligation, to a Gentleman in England; and out o' gratitude to him, ordered me on his Death bed, to beſtow my Siſter on his Son, and Heir, if his actions have any ſort o' ſmile in 'em to his incompatible Father, which is the query. Pray reſolve it.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Firſt let me know the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: You ſhall, I'le give you a Map of his Face, a Picture contain'd in my pocket.—ha!—I ha' loſt it,—I ha' loſt it—.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Tell me his Name, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: I ha' dropt it out o' my pocket.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I, but his name.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: I ha' dropt it out o' my pocket.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ha' you dropt his Name out o' your pocket? his Name Sir?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Oh! his Name, I'le tell you both his Name, and Cogname. His Name is Andrew, his Cogname Farewel.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Farewel? what comes into my head? Sir can you gueſs where you might looſe this Picture?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: A gueſs may be obtain'd—by the Prayers of Marriners—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: No other way? thoſe I ſeldome hear of—

sp.speaker: Cr
sp.p: —I was drawn down—ſtay let me ſee—remembrance begins to be idle—has London no place in the Weſt?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ay, no doubt.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Ay, but ſomething very Weſt? ſomething call'd Weſt?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Yes—there's VVeſt-Smithfield.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: That's not th' appellative. Is there no Monſter in the Weſt, call'd Weſtmonſter?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Weſtminſter I believe you mean.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Y'ave nick'd it it. To Weſtminſter I rode, to behold the Glorious circumſtances o' the Dead; and diving into my pocket, to preſent the repreſenter with a Gratification, I am fully confirm'd, I then loſt it; for my Eyes and the Picture had never any rencounter ſince.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: This exactly agrees with my Siſters ſtory, what a Prodigious thing is this? a diſcovery o' my Siſters innocence, ſent to me from th' Indies, in a heap o' Non-ſence? and in ſo Critical a minute; excellent Providence?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: What's an excellent Providence, Sir, that I ha' loſt my Picture?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: No Sir, that I ha' found your Picture.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Found my Picture?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, 'twas found by a Friend o' mine, in Weſtminſter-Abby—there it is—

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Oh! my Picture!—my Picture!—my Picture!—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Oh! my eas'd heart!

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Oh! my Picture! my Picture! my pretty Picture!
My Lord I muſt requite this favour, open that Casket, and give my Lord a handful of Diamonds.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: A handful o' Diamonds.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Ay, my Lord, I beg your Pardon for the inconſiderableneſs o' the Preſent.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Inconſiderableneſs? what a Market wou'd ſome make o' this Man?—put up your Diamonds.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: By no means, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Put 'em up Sir, or you'l diſſoblige me.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: You overwhelm me with Favours, I wiſh I had you at my houſe in Bantam.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I thank you, Sir; we are better where we are.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: My Lord, you put me under the circumſtance o' bluſhing.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Pray let me put you into a Chamber, to reſt your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Reſt is good—yours humbly—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Yours as humbly—What a Fire did I kindle in my houſe, to clear the Air of a Peſtilence, was not in it? my Siſter and all my Family are innocent. But what a fantaſtick thing is Womens Honour?

l.hi: Whil'ſt She enjoy it, 'tis not ſeen or known,
And yet when loſt She's utterly undone.

div.head: ACT. IV.
div.stage: The Scene continues. Enter Violante and Leonora laughing.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: HA! ha! ha! what an excellent Fellow is this? what Engines he has in his head? not only to wind himſelf into my Lords houſe, but the Picture out of his hands?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: He undertakes to bring Mr. Farewel hither to Night. If he engag'd to bring him in a Church with a Parſon to marry us, I wou'd not doubt it.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Certainly my Lord muſt be in a moſt mortified humour; now is the time to ſcarify him, and take out his Worm.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Here he comes, now will I carry my ſelf with all the inſolence of a Vertuous Woman.
So my Lord have your Slaves been gathering any more ſcatter'd ſmiles o' mine? what loads o' that Gold Sand have your Aſſes brought home?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: They have heard all, now I am aſham'd to ſhew my Face.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Come, my Lord, wou'd you confine a Woman of Honour? give her Liberty; wou'd you corrupt her? confine her.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: 'Tis true; were I a Wife to ſuch a Man, I ſhou'd abuſe him out o' Pride; and think my ſelf not an ill but a great Woman, ſince to puniſh is a mark of Princely Dignity.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: This I confeſs is the Engliſh Dialect; and when I talk of Governing Women, I talk of a thing not underſtood by our Nation. I admire how it came about, that we who are of all Nations, the moſt wiſe and free in other reſpects, ſhou'd be the only Slaves and Fools to Women.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Oh! you are the Wiſeſt of all Nations, you know let Men do what they can, Women will do what they pleaſe; and whereas other Nations by their ſpyes and Governantes are at great toyle and charges to be Cuckolds, you have it for nothing.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Come Brother, do not dreſs me in a Fools Coat, nor hang ſpyes about me, like ſo many gingling Bells, to give notice of all my motions. I can count, and know that one and one, put ſhamefully together, are two lewd Fools, and not one happy pair, as ill Women reckon, and deceive themſelves.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p:
Siſter, I believe you Virtuous, but I wou'd have you not only be Virtuous but thought ſo. And truly a Woman may be Virtuous, but is ſeldome
wiſe in Mens company. Her vain honour will put her on new Conqueſts. And Womens Conqueſts are pretty things; they often end like thoſe of Highway Men, in a ſhameful Execution on their one Perſons. And yet all the buſineſs of their lives is muſtering up Forces. To day the Beauty Lyes ambuſh'd in undreſſes, the hair pin'd up in Papers, like Serpents coyl'd to fly on you with greater force; the Garments are looſe and flowing as the Sea, to ſhew a Venus is there. To morrow ſhe's as regularly fortified as a Low Country Town, and oft a party of Charming looks are ſent abroad to put all Spectators under a contribution.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Your Wife muſt not dreſs?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Why ſhou'd ſhe? I think Womens Poynts and Embroyderies, but ſo many Billet-doux in Needle work.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: She muſt not go abroad or ſee a play.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Yes, She may go to Plays, provided ſhe'l ſee Plays and not Fools, it may be enter into Converſation with 'em, and inſtead of getting Wit from the Plays, get folly from the Fops; and ſo her Wit being ſpoyl'd in her Youth, ſhall like a Clock ſet wrong in the Morning, go falſe all the day after. In ſhort, no Wife or Siſter of mine ſhall dabble in converſation with any Man; I hate a Slattern in her credit.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: I' my conſcience I think I hear Belguard and his Miſtreſs quarrel in good earneſt.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Let no Woman marry a Man o' your humour, but ſhe that for her Crimes is condemn'd to Tranſportation. The Slave that in Virginia toyls to plant her Lord Tobacco, is not more miſerable, than ſhe that in your boſome Labours to plant a good opinion; both drudge for ſmoke. I ſcorn the ſlavery, nor will marry a King to encreaſe his Dominions, but to ſhare 'em.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I offer you the entire Dominion o' my ſelf; only deſire you, not to aim at further conqueſts.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I ſhou'd be a fine Soveraign, where Jealouſie, Pride, Rage, and ſuch a ſawcy Committee ſhall give me Laws; which they wou'd never do to a Prince they lov'd.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I think I've given convinceing Proofs of Love.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: When?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: When I offer'd, Madam, to take you for better and for worſe; thoſe are Heroical Complements. The form of Matrimony out-does Ovid for paſſionate expreſſions.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Ay, my Lord, but that's none o' your Wit, and I wou'd not have a Man o' your parts, ſteal other Mens Phraſes; ſo Your Lordſhips humble Servant.—Come away Child

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p:
Rare! they'r parted; once a Woman ſpoke truth. My Lord, your Servant. I've over heard your quarrel, and I honour you, you are the only Man in the Nation that underſtands himſelf. Lock up the Women till they'r muſty, better they ſhou'd have a Hogo, than their Reputations. And their
Honours are not like their Smocks, whitened by lying abroad.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Nor have their ador'd Faces the more eſteem, for often appearing.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: pox on 'em, they varniſh like Copper, and the Women are ſenſible of it, that's the reaſon they forge new faces every time they go abroad; and all the Arts of Paint and dreſs are ſuborn'd to give a Baſtard beauty Title to Reign, becauſe the Legitimate Face is fallen into contempt by familiarity. No more to be ſaid, keep your ground like a Man of honour; and looſe your Miſtreſs like a Coxcomb.—

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: An't pleaſe your Honour, Mr. Hothead and Mr. Teſtimony, are return'd, as your Honour gave order.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: That's well—come Mr. Teſtimony; here has been a miſtake gave me a harſh opinion of you—I'm ſorry for it.

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: Oh! My Lord, have a care of cenſuring Profeſſors—for a Profeſſor.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Nay, prethee don't profeſs too much. I am ſatisfied with thee.

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: Truly you would, if you knew of what a tender Spirit I am of. I was only deluded the other day into a Play-houſe, and truly it will be a burden to my Spirit whilſt I live.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: A lack a day, well I hope you'l be the more tender of my Siſter, your trouble will not be long. I have engag'd her to a Gentleman, whom about this time I expect. What a clock is it?

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: Truly I do believe it is about Four, I cannot ſay it poſitively; for I wou'd not tell a Lye for the whole World.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: This is an excellent Fellow, if he be what he pretends. (knocking. Hark! ſome one at the Door—may be 'tis he—ſee—

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Did you ſend for me, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ay, Couſin, to reconcile my ſelf to thee; I was in a miſtake.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: I think you was, when you judg'd a Raſcally Fanatick a better Man than I.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: The contrary Couſin—I think thee ſo much the better Man, I keep thee to have an eye over him, becauſe I don't know if he be a Knave.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Not know if a Fanatick be a Knave? You'r fit to ſit in the Houſe o' Peers I faith.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Well, thou art a very honeſt Fellow Couſin—let me have thy Company. But what are thoſe Patches on thy Face, for Ornament?

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: they are for Plaiſters, but they are Ornaments. I have been in a Fanatick Coffee-Houſe, and this is the Beauty they gave me.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: 'Twas to reward ſome honourable Names, thou gav'ſt 'em.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: I gave 'em no wrong names. I call'd 'em Rogues indeed, but that's their proper Name; and they all ſet their hands to it immediately, and ſubſcribed themſelves Rogues upon my Chops, the only true Narrative they ever writ.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Thou art a mad Fellow—prethee go in.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Well—who's at the Door?

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: A lamentable Soul.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: A Beggar?

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: A more ſad Object; but I conceive he comes rather to rob than beg, for he comes Arm'd with a ſtrong Bow and Arrows.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: A Bow and Arrows? what, is he a Tartar?

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: A Bow and Arrows made of Ribons, Laces, and other idle Vanities, wherewith he intends to wound your Siſter's heart.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Oh! the canting Coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: Nay, why canting Coxcomb?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Be gone you ſenceleſs Aſs; and bring in the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: Nay, why ſenceleſs Aſs? this is unſeemly.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: He wont ſtir.

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: I am no ſenceleſs Perſon—I ha' more ſences than your ſelf▪ I have a ſence o' Vanity, and of the nothingneſs o' the things o' this World—and a ſence o' Sin, and a ſence o' the inſinuating nature o' ſin—I dare not bring this wanton frothy young Man to your Siſter—for ſhe is frothy alſo—and ſin will get in at a little crany—and if ſin once get in his head, he'l get in all his whole body. now your honour has not that ſence o' theſe things. You ought to have that Your Honour is a ſenceleſs Perſon—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: —How Sirrah—?

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: In a ſpiritual ſence—.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: There's no getting this preaching Fellow away.—Couſin Hothead.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Why do you let this canting Coxcomb plague me?

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Why do you keep ſuch a canting Coxcomb? let him plague you, Pox you, and Damn you, I don't care.

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: Oh! ſad! oh! ſad!

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Oh! ſhad! oh! Sot!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: So, now I've brought 'em both upon me.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: He's always tuning his Noſe, too high too low, like a Sowgelders Horn

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Well, Sir, if you pleaſe, tell me who's at my Door?

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Forty One is coming in ding dong.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Into My Door? who's at my Door, I ſay?

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Old Forty One, I'faith.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I cannot have an anſwer—Sirrah—who's at my Door?

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: Popery, I'm ſure is coming in.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Into my Door? I ask you, who's at my Door?

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: Popery I'm ſure.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Roguery I'm ſure.

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: Popery I'm ſure.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Roguery I'm ſure.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Confound you both.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: And confound you both.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You Boy, is there any one at Door?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Yes my Lord.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: So, this Boy can anſwer, who is it?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Sir Courtly Nice, My Lord.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: O! theſe Rogues, have they made him wait all this while? introduce him quickly. He comes moſt ſeaſonably to rid me of my plague, now I'm very ſick of it.
sp.stage: Enter Sir Courtly and the Page, bowing to one another.
sp.p: Dear Sir Courtly, my Servants did not tell me who you were, that I have ignorantly made you wait, I am a ſham'd to ſee you.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Your Lordſhips moſt humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Your very humble Servant Page—call my Siſter.
sp.stage: goes to Salute Leo. Aunt steps firſt.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Madam your moſt—

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Sir Courtly, your very humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! your Ladyſhips very humble Servant—

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Your moſt humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Now Madam, your moſt humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: An incomparable fine Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Well, Sir Courtly, now I've brought you thus far o' your way to my Siſters inclinations; I'le leave you to purſue the reſt o' your journey by your ſelf; you need no guide to Ladies hearts.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! your moſt humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: No, Sir Countly commands all. If my Neice does not receive you, Sir Courtly, in all the obliging manner in the World, 'tis for want of experience and underſtanding merit—I'le aſſure you, Sir Courtly, I who have ſome little more judgment, have had a very particular value for you, Sir, from the firſt Minute I had the honour to ſee you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! Madam, your moſt humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: A very particular—

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! your moſt humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: And if my Neice has not, it proceeds from her want of Years to know Deſert. And indeed all Youth is indiſcreet, I wou'd by no means adviſe a Gentleman of Merit, to marry any Perſon, that has not ſome Years and experience upon her—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: She's ſetting up for her ſelf I think. Aunt.—

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Nephew—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Pray leave the Lovers together.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Sir Courtly, your moſt humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Sir. Co.
sp.p: Madam, your moſt humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Pray, Neice, behave your ſelf ſo to Sir Courtly, as at leaſt to do me right; and by all your expreſſions and behaviour, he may know how very particular an honour I have for him.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: She has for him?—

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Moſt particular.—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Pray Aunt in particular—come with me—

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Very particular—

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! Madam—Madam—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Aunt—

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Yes Nephew—Sir Courtly, I am exceeding unwilling to leave you to to the Converſation of a young Lady, whoſe Years I'm afraid will not afford her Wit enough to entertain ſo fine a Gentleman—

sp.speaker: Sir. Co.
sp.p: Oh! Madam! Madam! Madam!

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: But I'le return with all ſpeed poſſible.—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: But you ſhall not, if I can help it—

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: And ſo your very humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! Madam! your moſt humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Now will I manage him, humour him—pretend to admire him—to draw him into love, laugh at him and revenge my ſelf on him, for plaguing me.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Now, Madam, is the glorious opportunity come, which my Soul has long wiſh'd, to expreſs how much I admire, adore—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Oh! Sir Courtly—

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Extravagantly adore!—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Oh! Sir Courtly—I cannot receive all this.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! Madam, is there any thing on the Earth ſo charming?—I never ſaw any thing ſo fine as your Ladyſhip, ſince I was born.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Fye, Sir Courtly—

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Never ſince I was born—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: You'l kill me with bluſhing.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: I ſpeak my Soul—Heavens! what Divine Teeth there are?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Fye! fye! I ſhall never open my mouth more.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Then you'l undoe all the World. Oh! there's nothing ſo charming as admirable Teeth. If a Lady faſtens upon my heart, it muſt be with her Teeth.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: That's a pleaſant Raillery—ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! Madam, I hope your Ladyſhip has a better opinion o' my good Manners—Railly a Lady o' your quality?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Oh! you Wits, turn all things into ridicule.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Madam, I never was ſo ſerious ſince I was born; therefore I beſeech your Ladyſhip have pitty upon me.—I ſwear and vow if you do not, I ſhall dye.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Dye! ha! ha! you Wits will be raillying.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Heavens, Madam! how ſhall I convince you, I am ſerious.?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Really, Sir Courtly, I ſhou'd be very ſorry if you be ſerious.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! Heavens! why ſo Madam?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Becauſe 'tis pitty ſo fine a Gentleman ſhou'd loſe all his Gallantry—

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Now you frighten me, Madam. Is it impoſſible for me to attain the Glory of your inclinations?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: It will be impoſſible for me to keep the Glory of your inclinations, Sir Courtly; ſo I dare not venture on 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! as to that, Madam, I'le ſwear Eternal conſtancy, eternal ſervices, and all thoſe things.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: You are not in your own power, Sir Courtly. You fine Gentlemen, like fine Countries, are deſir'd and fought by all, and therefore in a perpetual War. If I ſhou'd place my heart in you, it wou'd not have a minutes quiet. A thouſand Potent Beauties wou'd every day aſſault you, and you'd yield out o' Complaiſance, your good Breeding wou'd undo me.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! Madam, this is extremity o' Gallantry; your Ladyſhip puſhes things to a ſtrange height.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I ſpeak my Soul. Beſides i've another humour, but that's a Foibleſs will ridicule me.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! Madam.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Nay i'le confeſs it. I am ſtrangely curious—extravagantly curious—I nauſeate a Perfume if it ever ſaluted any Noſe but my one.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! fortunate! my own humour.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Nothing muſt come near me, that was ever once touch'd by another.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Is it poſſible?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Not if you'd give a Hundred pound.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: My own Phraſe too, i've obſerv'd it in my ſelf, i'me ſtrangely fortunate—we ſhall be fond to an infinite degree.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: For that reaſon, your fine Gentlemen is my averſion, he's ſo tempted by all Ladies, ſo Complaiſant to all Ladies, that to marry a fine Gentleman, is to accept the leavings of a Thouſand Ladies.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! Madam! you ha' met with the Creature you deſire;—I never touch'd Woman ſince I was born.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: That's pleaſant, I believe you have ruin'd a thouſand.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Not one upon my Soul.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: 'Tis impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! Madam! there's not one Lady in a thouſand I can Salute. I only touch the tip o' their ear with my Cheek.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Fy! fye!

sp.speaker: Sir. Co.
sp.p: Not one Lady in a Million, whoſe breath I can endure. But I cou'd not go into their Beds, if you'd give me a Thouſand pound. I cou'd not come into the Ayr of any Bed in England but my own, or Your Ladyſhips, if you'd give me all the World.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: This is all Gallantry, Sir Courtly. You have been told this is my humour.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Is it really, Madam?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Oh! above all things. I ſuffer nothing to come near my bed, but my Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Nor I, but my Gentleman. He has a delicate hand at making a Bed, he was my Page, I bred him up to it.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: To making Beds?

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Ay, Madam, and I believe, he'l make a Bed with any Gentleman in England.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: And my Woman has a great Talent.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Is it poſſible? Ladies commonly employ ordinary Chamber Maids—with filthy Aprons on, made by ſluttiſh Women that ſpit as they—ſpin—foh!

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Foh!

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Your Ladyſhip will pardon me—my Linnen is all made in Holland, by neat Women that dip their Fingers in Roſe-water, at my charge.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Delicate.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: And all waſh'd there.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: And ſo is mine at Hearlem.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: At Hearlem, I hold a conſtant correſpondence with all the Eminent Waſhers there.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: That's delicate, and agrees wonderfully with my humour.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! happy! we ſhall be fond to an infinite degree.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Oh! foh! here's that beaſtly rude Clown Mr. Surly.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! foh! what ſhall we do with him?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: How now? how now? you two are intimate—heark you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Oh! foh!

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Foh!

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Foh! what's this fohing at?

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: No body Mr. Surly; only at preſent we are accoſted with an ungrateful ſmell.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Yes, I ſmell an ungrateful ſmell, your Rogury. Madam, I employ'd this Fellow to ſpeak for me, and i'le be hang'd if he be not falſe to me.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: To ſpeak for him? ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Ay, for him, Madam, ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Ay, for me Nickumpoop.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Your humble Servant Sir, y' are very civil.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: So I am, that I do not execute thee for this theft upon the place; but thou plead'ſt thy Face, as Whores do their Bellys; 'tis big with Fool.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Very civil—Sir.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Sure, Madam, a Woman o' your ſence, will not chuſe him before me. He has more Land? not more improv'd Land. His Acres run up to one great Weed, I mean himſelf; and there it Bloſſoms in Periwigs and Ribons. Oh! but he has a finer Perſon! that's a cheat; a falſe Creed impos'd on you, by a General Council of Taylors, Milleners and Sempſtreſſes; let my hat expound his Face, and youl ſee what a peice o' ſimple ſtuff it is.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Horrid! he has put his beaſtly Hat upon my Head—pray Sir do me the favour to remove it, or I ſhall grow very ſick—

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Sick? I hope thou wilt eat my Hat. Now, Madam, you ſee what a cheat he is, and whether he deſerves any more favours, then to be decently hang'd with the reſt of his Brothers.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: My Brothers hang'd, Mr. Surly?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: I mean the Pictures in the Hangings, for they and thou are all but Needle-work; and thou would'ſt ſerve for a peice o' Tapſtery, but for a Husband, Lord, ha' Mercy on thee.

sp.speaker: Sir. Co.
sp.p: Your Servant, Mr. Surly. You are a very well bred Gentleman, Sir, and pay great Veneration to a Lady o' Quality, and your Miſtreſs—ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: His Miſtreſs? ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Let's railly him to death, Madam—ha! ha!—

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Railly? does the ridiculous Figure pretend to laugh at any thing?

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Dee' hear, Madam?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Sir Courtly, you are a Martyr to good manners, and ſuffer out o' reſpect to me, more than is fit for a Man to bear.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: He a Man? I ha' ſeen a Butler make a better thing out of a Diaper Napkin.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Your moſt obliged humble Servant—Sir.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Sir Courtly, I'le withdraw, that you may do your ſelf Juſtice—and be kick'd—

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Your Ladyſhips moſt humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I'le no longer protect ſuch a Coxcomb—as your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Your very humble Servant, Madam; I'le puſh his Soul out preſently.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Oh! don't do him that favour, Sir, only correct him.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Well, Madam, what your Ladyſhip pleaſes.—
Your Ladyſhips very humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Mr. Surly,
sp.p: I have receiv'd ſome favours from you, Sir, and I deſire the Honour of your Company, Sir, to Morrow morning at Barn-Elms, Sir,—pleaſe to name your Weapon, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: A Squirt.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: A Squirt?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Ay, for that will go to thy heart, I'm ſure.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Well, Sir, I ſhall kiſs your hands.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Kiſs my Breech.—

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Beaſt, Clown, Fool, Raſcal. Pox take him—what ſhall I do with him? it goes againſt my ſtomach horribly to fight ſuch a Beaſt. If his filthy Sword ſhou'd touch me, 'twou'd make me as ſick as a Dog.
sp.stage: Scene a Garden. Enter Cr. and Leonora.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Ha! ha! I'le ſecure the Coxcomb—I'le get him confin'd upon the Guard, among Tobacco takers and that will confine him to his Bed and Bagnio's for one Month.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: That will do rarely. About this time I expect Mr. Farewel, I ha ſent for your Brother to introduce him.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: My Brother?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Your Brother I ſay, to ſhew my skill. Retire, and ſtay conceal'd in the Garden. Here your Brother comes.
Now for lies and nonſence to entertain this jealous Brother till the Lover comes.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Sir Thomas your Servant, what's your will with me?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Talk—I love talk—begin.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Very pithy.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: In what circumſtance are we?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Circumſtance?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Ay, what call you this, where we are?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: A Garden.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: A Garden? i've ſeen in the Indies a Melon as big.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: As all this Garden?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Bigger.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Well lyed of a Mad-man. (aſide.) Are all your Fruit ſo large?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: All.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Your Nutmegs and Pepper are not.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Your Hiſtory is erronious. We have Nutmegs as big as ſmall Fly-boats, I have ſail'd a hundred Leagues in a Nutmeg.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Well lyed.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Our Oyſters have wonderful conferrence.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Circumference I ſuppoſe you mean.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Y' ave nick'd it. Three of 'em block up a Harbour. 'Tis our way of Mortification.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Fortification.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: You are in the right—Pox on't I have been ſo long abroad, I have almoſt forgot my Mother tongue.
Well—when will this Lover come? 'tis near the hour, and delicately dark.
Murder! murder! murder!

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: That's he! he's come! (aſide.) murder cryed out.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And at my Coach-houſe Door?
Oh! Cowardly Rogues! Four upon one.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: A Gentleman aſſaſſinated?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Open the Door.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Call ſome o' the Servants to aſſiſt a Gentleman, ſet upon at my Coach-Houſe Door.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Ay—quick—quick—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: How, Sir Thomas? will you venture among 'em?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Dee' think I wont? a Gentleman and not fight?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I muſt not ſuffer it, you may be hurt.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: No Sir, I'le fight like a Gentleman; I'le come by no hurt I'le warrant you.—Come quick—quick—open the Door—
Now Sound a Trumpet, Tivy—tivy—tan tan—tivy—Tone,—Pox on't 'tis a Horn—I don't know a Horn, I ha' forgot every thing belongs to a Gentleman.—among 'em—helter skelter—
sp.stage: (Exit Bel. Cr. and Ser. mean while Farewel ſteals into the Garden.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I' my conſcience this is Cracks deſign to let in Mr. Farewel.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Dear Madam you are in the right.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Mr. Farewel? I know your voice—

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Oh! Madam, I adore you for this bounty.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: And I ſhou'd bluſh for it.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Why ſo, Madam?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Shou'd a Woman admit a Lover by night at a Back-Door into the ſame houſe wher ſhe lyes, and converſe privately with him before Marriage.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Your Brother admitted me.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: 'Tis true indeed, you may thank him for the favour, I thought your ſufferings deſerv'd pity, and my Brother wou'd let me ſhew it, no other way.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: A thouſand Bleſſings on you.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I doubt not but my honour is very ſafe in your keeping, I wiſh your Perſon, were as ſecure in mine.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: I am glad o' the danger, ſince tis ſome aſſurance o' my Love.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Your Friend Mr. Crack plays his part very well, and I doubt not but he will ſecure us here, and conveigh us hence, but then other dangers will follow you.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: What are thoſe, Madam?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: The danger of marrying without a Fortune, my Ten thouſand pound is at my Brothers diſpoſe.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: I am glad of that too, Madam, 'twill ſhew my love is not mercenary.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: The danger of being laught at by the Wits, for marrying at all.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Oh! let the Wits keep the Jilting rotten Wenches, and leave the ſweet Virtuous Ladies to us marrying Fools, I can be as well pleas'd to keep a fine Wife to my ſelf, as they can be to maintain five Wenches for all the Town.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Nay, your keeping Men, Keepers like have commonly but the Offals for their Slave. Well the Evening Ayr will be unwholſome to you, if you ſtay longer in it, you'l be in danger of Thunder and Lightning preſently, I mean my Brother—he comes—follow me—

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: What Cowardly Rogues were theſe? they ran upon our firſt ſallying.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: They had a reaſon, you'r a Lyon.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: I us'd to kill Lyons and Tygers in the Indies, as you do Hares and Conyes here. I kept a Tyger Warren, I kill'd a brace every morning to get me a ſtomack.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: It was a good one ſure, you offer'd dear for it. Well I hope you ha' got no hurt?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Yes, ſomething very ſharp, went quite through my ſtomack.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: How? through your ſtomack? then you cannot live.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Yes, if you noint it preſently with a good diſh o' Jelly-broth, and Tent it with a bone o' Roaſt-beef.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Is that the wound? it ſhall be heal'd preſently.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Preſently, for my ſtomack is Captious.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: It ſhall be done. Go to my Aunt and deſire her to order Sir Thomas his Supper—

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: She's not very well, my Lord, and gone to bed.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Then let the Steward do it. Sir Thomas I am going out and ſhall ſtay late. Pray command my houſe—good Night to you—

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Your Servant Sir—you keep a Woman?—now to the Lovers—where are they?—
sp.stage: Enter Farewel, Leo. and her Woman.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Here! here! thou Divine Fellow.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: So, ſo, kiſs! kiſs! kiſs!—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Before Marriage?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Ay, for fear you ſhou'd not kiſs after marriage—well the houſe is our own, and the Night our own—your Aunts gone to bed, and your Brother abroad, we'l Tory—rory, and 'tis—a fine Night, we'l Revel in the Garden—Slaves go bring my Supper—quick—quick—
sp.stage: Ex. Slaves—and enter with Diſhes: Farewel, Leo. and Crack ſit down.
sp.p: Now a Song and Dance o' your own faſhion—but ſhut the Garden. Gates—and look to 'em well, for I'le be private in my pleaſures—
—So—now to my Chamber—well—there is no publick Officer like your Pimp—.

l.hi: Pimps manage the great buſineſs o' the Nation.
That is—the Heavenly work o' propagation.

div.head: ACT. V.
div.stage: Scene Cracks Chamber. Enter Farewel and Crack.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: OH! thou Divine Fellow, what joys haſt thou procured me?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: What joys?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: All that Innocence cou'd afford.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Innocence? that's inſipid ſtuff.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: No Mr. Crack, there's difference between the Mannah that came, from Heaven, and that out of 'Pothecaries Shops; a touch of Leonora's hand like Mannah from Heaven has all that Man can fancy. Here ſhe comes.
This, Madam, is bountiful after an Evenings Converſation, to afford me a Morning too.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: We ſhou'd be charitable • o Priſoners.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: I am a Priſoner, but ſuch a happy one, as a King is when Lodg'd in a Royal Tower, to prepare for his Coronation. My hour of Coronation draws near, I want only the Church Ceremony and the Oath.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Madam, how dirſt you venture hither, by day light?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: My Aunt, and Brother, are both gone abroad, and won't come home till Noon. So all thoſe hours are mine, and now Mr. Crack to requite your Muſick I ha' brought ſome o' mine to entertain you.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: Oh! Madam—undone—your Brother.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: How? how?

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: Juſt coming up ſtairs, to viſit—you Sir Thomas.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Pox of his civility. Hide, Sir Hide. And do you Women ſhreike!—ſhreike! and cry out murder.
sp.stage: Cr. throws himſelf on the ground and ſcrambles in diſtracted poſtures after the Women. They ſhreike—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: So, here's my Siſter got into the Madmans Room; and has put him into a frantick fit. Oh! the inſatiable curioſity o' Women.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: You Whores!—you bewitching Whores, do you come to bewitch me? I'le fetch blood from you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Why wou'd you offer to come hither, Siſter?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: What are you, Sir, the King of Bantam?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: No Sir, no.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Oh! the Mogul.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Nor the Mogul.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: What do you then with all theſe Concubines?—Oh! I know you now, you'r a fine man, you have put me into brave circumſtances. Did not I deſire you to let me ſee no Women? and here, you keep a company o'rambling Whores in your houſe, that have put me into the circumſtances o' diſtraction. I was a top o' the Staircaſe taking a proſpect o' the Cape of Good-Hope, and theſe Flyboats came ſayling under my Noſe. What do me I? but leap down to break their Necks? and ha' broke my own I think. I am certain, I have broke ſomething, but what I don't know. Pray take me up, and look over my bones, ſee if none be miſſing; if they be, Bone for Bone will be demanded.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Poor creature! who's there?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Who's there? will you truſt me to your ſervants! ſo if a Leg or an Arm of mine be broke, they'l leave it behind e'm, and I ſhall looſe it. I expect all my Limbs and Bones from you, as you received 'em. So—come and take account of 'em.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I will—I will—

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Oh! have a care—Oh!—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Alas! I fear he's hurt; your fooliſh curioſity ha's done this? did you not gape enough upon him before?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Oh! gently! gently!—ſo—ſo—

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Oh! this pleaſant Rogue! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Tis an excellent fellow. As ſoon as we hear my Brother is returning, ſlip into that paſſage, 'twill lead you to Crak's Bed-chamber.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: How now Gentlewoman? a man wi' you? Nephew—Nephew—Nephew.—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Begone—begone—through that Entry.
sp.stage: Ex. Fa. at one Door, at another Enter Bellguard.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Our family's diſhonour'd, diſhonour'd—here was a fellow, a handſome young fellow wi' my Neice. Oh! my fleſh! my fleſh.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Wi' me?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Will you deny it Confidence?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Who's there? Hothead, Teſtimony, all of you come hither.

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: What's your honours pleaſure?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: To cut all your throats, you are all Bauds and Villains.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Leave me out o' the number you had beſt.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I will not Sir, For here was a young fellow wi' my Siſter;

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: My Aunt's whimſy and jealouſie.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: I cou'd tread you under my feet.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Which way went he?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Into that paſſage: He cannot be got further, then Sir Thomas Calicoes Bed-chamber.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Lock all the doors, Arm and beſet Sir Thomas Calicoes lodgings.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: This will prove ſuch another wiſe buſineſs as the Picture.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Hold your peace—get you into that room wi' my Aunt. Aunt pray look to her.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: I'le keep her, I warrant her—come in gentlewoman.—you are a fine gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Oh! my heart trembles—Heaven inſpire Crack.
sp.stage: Ex. Aunt and Leonora. Scene changes to another Room.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Oh! curſed fortune.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Well don't trouble your ſelf. I'le bring you off ſafe.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Not trouble my ſelf, when Leonora's honour is in danger? ſhe'l be the jeſt of every prating Fop, and malitious beauty.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Her honour ſhall be ſafe too. This bluſtering—Brother ſhall entertain you.—

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: With a Blunderbuſs?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Ay, full o' Claret. Away—away—he comes?
sp.stage: Ex. Fa. and Enter Bellguard, Hothead, Teſtimony, and the Servants arm'd.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: How? the High and glorious Emperour o' Siam with all his guards? Thou moſt invincible Paducco, Farucco,—nelmocadin—bobbekin—bow——wow—ww—why doſt thou ſeek to deſtroy us Engliſh, ſeated on thy Dominions by thy own Letters Patents?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Piſh!—take him away.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Take away our Priviledges? then this goes to my heart.
sp.stage: Draws his Dager, and pretends to ſtab himſelf.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Hold, hold—Sir Thomas—Sir Thomas, no hurt is ment to you.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Moſt Great and Glorious Emperour, I humbly thank, and do humbly Implore thee; that thou wou'dſt command thy Invincible guards, to lay down their arms, and put us out of our frights, and we'l ſubmit our perſons to thee. This is ſome Interlopers work.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p:
Pox o' this impertinent mad—coxcombe? Lay down your weapons,
may be if we humour him, he may come to his ſences, and give us leave to ſearch the rooms.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: My Lord Bellguard, your moſt humble ſervant.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: He's come to himſelf; that's well. Sir Thomas your ſervant, how do you?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: A little diſcompos'd, ſomething has frightned me, and put me into the circumſtance of a ſweat.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I'me ſorry for that. Shall I beg leave, to ſearch your rooms for a theif that's got in?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Pardon's beg'd; ſearch muſt not be made; for I have a friend there, you muſt not ſee. Wou'd you and your friend were hanged.
A very honeſt Gentleman, but very much addicted to marriage. 'Tis he that I told you, is to marry my Indian Fubs of a Siſter—Mr Farewel.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Mr. Farewel?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Ay, hearing of my arrival, and what circumſtance I was in; hover'd all this morning about the houſe to get a ſight o' me; but car'd not to come in, for it ſeems there is enmity between you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: 'Tis True, and I wonder how he got in without my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: I made him come in. I was throwing my legs about in the Hall, and the door being open, our eyes knock'd immediately, and gave remembrance ſuch a bang, that we ran full ſpeed into the circumſtances of embracing?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And pray who ſaw this?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Who ſaw? what care I who ſaw? I care not if the whole Town ſaw, I'm not aſham'd of owning Mr. Farewel.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: No Sir, but I mean which of my family ſaw? that I may thank 'm for their care.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: What do I care for your family? if I may not bring a friend into your family, a fart for your family.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Nay be not angry Sir Thomas, your friend's welcome.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: I doubt it not, for I have found you a very civil perſon. And now recollection is active, I fancy he's the man you take for a theif. Tis ſo—ha! ha!—excuſe me—ha! ha!—leave is implord—ha! ha!—brot'her Farewel.
Brother.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Come out, and participate o' laughter.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: So, now have I play'd the fool again, vex'd my ſelf, and wrong'd my Siſter with my impertinent jealouſies.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Come brother—ha! ha! laugh—but firſt ſalute.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p:
My Lord, I believe you wonder to ſee me here, and you may; I call my ſelf Baſtard, and renounce the blood o' my family, by coming under your roof with any deſign, but to prejudice you, which at preſent I muſt acknowledge to my ſhame is not my intention. I viſit my friend here for his
own ſake, and the ſake of a great Beauty, which you ſhall not hinder me of, My Lord.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I will not Mr. Farewel, I ſcorn thoſe effeminate revenges. If I hurt any Man it ſhall be with my Sword.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Your Sword, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Hold? hold.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ay any where but here Mr. Farewel, my Houſe is your Sanctuary, and here to offer you violence, wou'd prejudice my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: What a quarrelling's here? i'my conſcience I believe, my Lord, 'tis becauſe you think he came to ſteal me, I being under whimſical circumſtances, for I remember you call'd him a Thief. Look you, My Lord don't fear me, I won't be ſtole—I know when I'm well—Brother I'm very well provided for, I want nothing but my Wits; and what do they ſignifie? if a Man lives like a Gentleman, no matter whether he has Wit or no—

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Well, my Lord, though I have the misfortune to be your Enemy, I am none to good manners; I am ſorry I ha' given your houſe this trouble, and the more becauſe my Friend receives ſuch generous uſage in it.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Nor am I an Enemy to Love, and the fair Sex. If the Lady you come for loves you, for her ſake I wiſh you ſucceſs.—

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Now my Lord you vanquiſh me.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: He's a brave Man—Faith.—

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: I fancy we ſhall live to be better Friends, at preſent I'le take my leave,—my Lord your Servant.—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Your Servant Sir.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Brother I muſt ſee you down ſtairs. This was a Maſter-peice. ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Now I am cool again. What a flame had your negligence put me into. Here releaſe my Siſter, I'm aſham'd to ſee her—

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Sirrah! Sirrah! you did this to make me ſuſpected.

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: Ay—ay, I muſt be abus'd, becauſe I'm a Proteſtant.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: A Proteſtant? a Dog. But with ſuch Names the Rogues divide the Rabble, and make the Nation go like the Devil, upon Cloven Feet.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Hold your prating, and by your future care make amends for your paſt negligence; your trouble ſhall not be long, within this Eight and forty hours I'le marry her, or ſend her into the Country.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Well—well—I'le look to her, for the Honour of my Family, not your huffing.

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: I to diſcharge a Conſcience—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: So—Sir—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: My Siſter—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Do you run from me? is that the reparation you make for the intolerable wrongs you have done me?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p:
Well, I have wrong'd you, I'm ſorry for it, and beg your Pardon—
I muſt be gone—about buſineſs—your buſineſs—to fetch Sir Courtly Nice. your Servant, Siſter.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Oh! your Servant Sir—ha! ha!—he runs—I may chance Sir to run as nimbly from you, if Cracks Wit do not fail him—here he comes—
Thou admirable Fellow, what haſt thou done with Mr. Farewel?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: He's in the Street ſtaying for you.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Staying for me? and can'ſt thou conveigh me to him?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Dee' queſtion it? put on a Vizard and ſomething over your Cloaths.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Sweet Rogue.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Nay, nay be gone.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Delicate Rogue.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Nay, nay he ſtays for you.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Incomparable Rogue.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Pſhaw! put on your Vizard.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Moſt excellent Rogue.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Oones! put on your Vizard.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I will—I will—ha! ha! toll—loll—derol—
sp.stage: Cr. goes out, and as Leo. is going out ſinging and danceing, She's met by Bell. and Sir Co.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Oh! Siſter your tune's alter'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! Madam! I'm happy to find your Ladyſhip, in ſo gay a humour.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: You'l not find it ſo—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Sir Courtly I'le betray her to you. I left her in Tears upon an unhappy occaſion, and at parting told her I wou'd bring you. Now you are come, I find her in joy. Nothing elſe cou'd cauſe the change.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! fortunate.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Oh! Fop!—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Now improve your intereſt, and let us ſee how great a Maſter you are in Courtſhip, by your dextrous diſpatch. I leave you together—

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: And upon my Soul I will. Oh! Madam, am I ſo Fortunate, ſo Glorious, to be well in your fine inclinations?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Oh! fye, Sir Courtly—if I had any ſuch guilt upon me, do you think I wou'd confeſs?

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: You do confeſs, Madam—your fine Eyes, and your languiſhing Ayr, and your charming Bluſhes, and all thoſe things—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I hope I carry no ſuch falſe things about me; for if they ſay any ſuch thing they infinitely wrong me.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! now you are cruel, Madam; you kill me.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Can you hope for my heart Sir Courtly, till I've ſome aſſurance o' yours.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: What aſſurance wou'd your Ladyſhip have?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p:
All manner—he that pretends to my heart—muſt ſigh, and wait,
and watch—and pant—and fight, and write—and kill himſelf.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: All this I ha' done, Madam, and Ten thouſand things more. Drove by your Windows, a thouſand times a day, ſought you at the Parks and the Plays. Was a conſtant faithful Attendant at all Tragedys—for I preſum'd your Ladyſhip nauſeates Comedys—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Oh! Foh!—

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: They are ſo ill—bred—and ſawcy with Quality, and always cram'd with our odious Sex—that have not always the moſt inviting ſmell—Madam, you'l Pardon me—Now at Tragedies, the Houſe is all lin'd with Beauty, and then a Gentleman may endure it. And I have gone, found not your Ladyſhip there, drove home, kill'd my ſelf with ſigthing, and then writ a Song.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Oh! Heavens! Sir Courtly, did you ever write a Song upon me?

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Above a thouſand.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Oh! there's nothing charms me like a Song—
For Heavens ſake—the Song!—the Song—

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: I've above forty here in a ſweet Bag, I'le ſhew you the firſt I made upon Your Ladiſhip. 'Tis thought to be a pretty Fooliſh ſoft Song, moſt Ladies are very kind to it.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Oh! Sir Courtly—

l.hi: Which you did wi' ſuch art;

sp.speaker: Leo
sp.p: Oh! fine! oh! fine!

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: That ſtop Thief, Madam, is pretty Novel.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Oh! delicate! I'm charm'd! I'm loſt!—fye what have I ſaid—

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: What makes me the happyeſt of Creatures.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I only railly—I renounce all—

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Not for the World—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Away—the Song again—the Song—I'le hear nothing but the Song. Is there no tune to it?

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: One of my own compoſing.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: That accompliſhment to? Heavens! how fine a Gentleman is this?

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! Madam, how prou'd you make me?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Oh! dear, how I betray my ſelf? fooliſh Creature—no more—no more—the Tune, the tune.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: I always humour my words with my Ayr. So I make the Voice ſhake at the laſt Line, in imitation of a Man that runs after a Thief. Sto—ho—ho—hop—Thief—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Oh! delicate! cannot I learn it? ſto—ho—ho—ha! ha! ha!
sp.stage: (imitates his Fooliſh ſinging and falls into a laugh.)

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Dear Madam, what makes your Ladyſhip laugh?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: At a Coxcomb, that thought to win me with a Fooliſh Song, this puts it into my head.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! Fooliſh! there are abundance of thoſe Fooliſh Fellows, and does the Song pleaſe your Ladyſhip?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Infinitely, I did not think you had been ſo fine a Poet.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Poetry, Madam, is my great foible, and when I ſee a fine Woman I cannot command my foible.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: How? dee' make Songs upon other Ladies? unfortunate I've given my heart to aninconſtant Man—

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! Madam,—only Gallantry.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I'm abus'd—unfortunate—

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! Madam, you take it wrong—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I'm abus'd.—

sp.speaker: Sir. Co.
sp.p: Oh! Heavens!

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: But the Songs very fine!—ſto—ho—ho—ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Pleaſant Creature.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Coxcomb.—

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: We ſhall be infinitely fond—a pretty Glaſs, this Madam

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: So he's making an aſſignation with his own fooliſh Face, I'le leave him to Court that and ſteal away.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Sto—ho—ho—hop—

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Singing, Sir Courtly?

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: At your Service, Madam. Well, Madam, you have ſaid ſo many fine things to me, that I aſſure my ſelf of your heart, and now I am reſolv'd to puſh this opportunity, to an extremity o' happyneſs.
sp.stage: (Sir Courtly looks in the Glaſs while he ſpeaks.)

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Oh! fortunate! this to me? I did make him ſome advances to day I confeſs, and have they had this ſucceſs? my heart pants: I am ſurpris'd with infinite joy, and am not able to anſwer—

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Well, Madam, I muſt be happy, and ſo upon my—the Lady gone—

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Sir Courtly you put me in great confuſion—

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: The Lady's conſent is very conſiderable—ſhe governs her Neice, and under her conduct may make me happy, with a reſerve to Modeſty. (aſide.) Well, Madam, ſhall I have your conſent to my happyneſs, my glory?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Oh! dear Sir! is it poſſible to anſwer you ſo ſoon?

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: So ſoon, Madam? you know my paſſion has been long.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Is it poſſible? I ſwear I never heard of it before.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: That's ſtrange; wou'd not my Lord, your Nephew acquaint you?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: He never ſaid one word of it to me.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: That's amazing.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: I find my Nephew has been falſe to me. It ſeems 'tis me the Gentleman loves, and my Nephew wou'd defrau'd me of him, for his Siſter—heres fine doings.—

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: I ſwear I thought your Ladyſhip had known, and granted your conſent—you ſaid ſo many fine things—

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: I ſaid no more,—Sir Courtly, then what were the reſult o' my thoughts, upon the contemplation of your great deſert—

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Your Ladyſhips moſt humble Servant—then I hope, Madam, ſince my paſſion has been long, though you knew not of it, you will not deferr my hapyneſs—'tis in your power I'm certain, no Perſon controuls you—

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Controuls me? that's pleaſant—no Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: She ſays true—ſhe can bring her Neice— (aſide.) I beſeech you, Madam, take pity of a ſuffering Lover.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Oh! Sir, ſhou'd I conſent ſo ſoon, 'twou'd be againſt all Forms.—

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: I would not for the World offend againſt any Forms. No Man living more ſtudyes, and adores all manner of Forms—but my paſſion has been long.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: I know not what to ſay, Sir, indeed I muſt not.—

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! Pardon me!

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Oh! Pardon me!

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! Madam!

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: You confound me, Sir:

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: You diſtract me, Madam. It muſt be.—

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Well, Sir I yield, but with an extremity o' bluſhing.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Your moſt obliged humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: My ſevere temper wou'd never ha' been wrought on ſo ſoon, but by ſo fine a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Your moſt humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: And to revenge my ſelf on my Nephew, for his falſe play.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Well, Madam, we'l in my Coach to the next Church preſently.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: 'Tis very hard to reſiſt you, Sir Courtly. If you pleaſe I will firſt put on a Diſguiſe; for I deſire it may be manag'd with all ſecrecy, till the Ceremony of Marriage be over.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: With all my Soul; for I infinitely love a ſecret Intrigue, eſpecially when every body knows of it.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Leaſt my Nephew light on us, and prevent it.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: He's for the Match.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: He's very falſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Is it poſſible?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Is it not apparent, when he conceal'd the whole matter from me, leaſt I ſhou'd promote it?

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: That's unanſwreable, I'm amaz'd at it. Well, Madam, I ſhall not fail of being happy?—

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Immediately, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: And you think you have power?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Power? that's pleaſant.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: So—ſo—ſhe'l bring or ſend her— (aſide.) Well, Madam, Your moſt humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Your very bluſhing Servant—

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Your humble—ſto—ho—ho—hop—Thief—

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: An humble Thief indeed, ſteal an old Woman?—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: This was a pleaſure I cou'd not ha' thought of. Now to our Affair.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Come—on with your Vizard.
sp.stage: Scene changes to the Hall. Enter at one Door, Hothead and Teſtimony, at another Crack.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Barbarity! falſehood! treachery! murder

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Did not I ſtipulate upon the ſurrendry of my ſelf to this Houſe, to be kept from Women? and I am devour'd with e'm; here's come into my Chamber, a hot burnt Whore, with a black cruſt upon her face—here ſhe is, Avant.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: You damn'd Whore, how came you into this houſe? and what are you? I'le ſee your face.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Then I'le ſee your braines, I ſwear by Gogmagog, and all the ſeven damnable Sinnes.

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: Oh! ſad! oh! ſad

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Shew me the face of a Woman? I had rather ſee forty full moons.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Stand off Impertinence; I will ſee her face.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Murder! murder! call my Lord—Lord, Lord—murder—murder! Lord—Lord—Lord.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Hold your bauling, I'le let her go.—For now I think on't, If my Lord ſhou'd find this Whore here when he gave ſuch ſtrickt orders, we ſhou'd let no body out, or in, he'l make more noiſe than this mad fool—ſo let us kick her out o' Doors, and ſay nothing.

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: Hold, let us not uſe violence to her—ſhe's a great temptation to me. (aſide) I'le reprove the idle Woman, it may be, I may gain upon her.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Gain a Clap Sirrah! for this is ſome of the footmens Whores, pick'd up in the dark. Get you out you Whore.

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: No violence pray. She's a great ſnare to me. (aſide.) woman get you out woman—and dee hear?—I'le follow you, and we'l drink a bottle.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Do old godly knave, and thou ſhalt be welcome.

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: I come! I come! (aſide) get you out woman.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Get you out—you Whore.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Good morrow—up ſo early?

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: What's the whimſy now?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Am not I i' Bed?

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: In Bed?

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: Poor ſoul, poor ſoul—

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: I am not i' faith. Then I walk in my ſleep: I was faſt a ſleep juſt now, and dream't I ſaw women, and Vizards, and all that Traſh; and the fright put me in a Feaver. I burn; prethee give me a mouth full of ſweet ayr.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Prethee take a belly full and be damn'd. A fine time on't I have; with Whores, and Fools, and mad Men, and Fanatiques.

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: So, now I'le ſteal after her; for I find in me a very great uproar.
sp.stage: Scene changes to Violante's houſe. Enter Farewel—Leonora vizarded, Teſtimony.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Come in, come in honeſt old Fornicator, though the girle be mine, when I have had my collation, if ſhe'l conſent, faith, thou ſhalt have a bit; I love a Wenching Rogue i' my heart.

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: Oh! dear Sir, your very humble ſervant, and truly I am a kind of a wag. I love a pretty bit ſometimes.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: And I love thee the better for it, and this is a pretty bit, thou ſhalt ſee her

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: Oh! dear! undone! undone!

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Nay, nay Mr. Teſtimony won't you be as good as your word? ſhan't we have a Bottle?

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: Oh! Madam, don't diſcover me to my Lord, and you ſhall not only have my prayers, but the prayers of all the ſober party for you all days o' my life.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: So, he runs from Whoring to Praying.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Are not you a Rogue Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: I know I ſhall be called Rogue, by the Popiſh party—they will rejoyce at my fall, but I hope my fall will be ſanctified unto me for my better Upſtanding.—

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Among the Wenches—Sirrah—come, Sirrah, you ſhall ſtay till my Lord comes, for his mortification, as well as yours.

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: Oh! my fleſh, it has undone me.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: My dear.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: My dear.—

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Excellent Crack; for this great peice o' ſervice, I'le ha' thee knighted under a petticote. Well we muſt ſend for my Lord, to laugh at him.

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: Oh! dear! I tremble!

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Who's there? well my Lord, I deſire to ſpeak with him.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Pray let him bring Sir Courtly Nice, and his bride with him; be ſure you ſay nothing o' me.—

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Are you a Bride yet?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Not yet.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Get in, and let my Chaplain make you one.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Come Mr. Teſtimony. Mr. Crack, bring him.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: How now you Rogue? what's your buſineſs?

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: Oh! my reproach will be great.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Mr. Surly.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Well, what now?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Now, you ſhall be my Husband.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Your Jack, to turn and roaſt you for another, whilſt I ha' no ſhare in you.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: According to the ſhare I have in you: You men wou'd feign engroſs all manner o' Sinnes, by the pretended Prerogative o' your Sex; well if iniquity be your Eſtate, when you ha' married me, I'le put in for my thirds.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: I doubt it not; within this week, I ſhall ſee in a Fop's hand, a Billet Doux, that is a Ticket to let him into your Play-houſe.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Prethee leave of this doged humour.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: I ha' none; fawning is a Dogs humour.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Nay but Sullenneſs; it taxes thy Eſtate, that thou art never the better for it; tis a french Eſtate.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Ay, but to lick a fool's ſhoe, is a Spaniels Eſtate.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Prethee dreſs like a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: So I do,; but I wou'd not dreſs like a Gentleboy, lag at my years among thoſe Children, to play with their Toys; be always followed up like a love letter, with a ſuperſcription, theſe to the next pretty girle.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: There's no altering thee—go in a while.
sp.stage: Ex. Surly. Enter Lord Belguard, Sir Courtly, Aunt vizarded.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: My Lord, your humble ſervant. I invited you hither, to reconcile you to your Siſter, ſhe's weary of your Government, and has diſpos'd of herſelf.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ay, Madam, but according to my own deſires, that now I ſuppoſe you will acknowledge the good effects of my Government;—Siſter ſalute your friend.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Do you take that for your Siſter? then I'le ſhew you the good effects of your Government. Open the Door.
sp.stage: The Scene is drawn, and Farewel, Leonora, a Parſon, Crack, Teſtimony, appear.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: My Siſter there? call my ſervants.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Nay then call mine, the great Mogul, and the King o' Bantam, I'le pepper you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Then you were the Pimp were you—Sirrah—I may chance begin with you.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: How? i' my houſe and preſence? touch him if you dare.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I'm made an Aſs on.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Not far from that circumſtance.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You Raſcal—

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Again?

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: But what the Devil am I made? what have I got?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Even my ſtale Aunt.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Sawcy huzzy.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: The Aunt? what have you put upon me, Madam?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: What have I put upon you, Sir, more than your ſelf deſir'd? Did not you declare you have long had a paſſion for me?

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: A Paſſion for you? Comical! that's probable! Rot me if ever I had a Paſſion for you in my Life. I meant all to your Neice; a Paſſion for an old Woman?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Ill-bred Fop.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Very fine—

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Now, my Lord, what ſay you of your fine Cotqueen art of Conſerving Woman? will ſhe keep if not candied with Virtue? here is a peice o' dryed Sweet-meat, you ſee cou'd not keep; and proves by her example, that the Hufls of either Sex, when they are boldly attacqued in private, ſooneſt deliver their Weapons.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: This is all ill manners.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Ay, but here's an old Cat will ſuffer no Vermin to come into the Houſe; but then he has a Liquoriſh tooth, and loves to have a ſweet bit for himſelf; he wou'd fain ha' pick'd up your Siſter for a Wench.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.p: 'Tis true indeed my Lord; I will not tell a lye for the whole World.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Oh! Villain—well Sirrah—I'le leave you to my Couſin Hotheads correction.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: But your faults my Lord I'le take into my correction, and give my ſelf to Mr. Surly—! Mr. Surly.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Well—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: To Surly?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Ay, now Nico thy quarrel and mine is at an end, Ile let thee be an Aſs forty years longer.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: You are a rude fellow and you are all ill—bred—and I'le revenge my ſelf on you all, as far as my Sword and my Wit can go—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Wit—ha! ha—

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: —Very fine manners this—my Coach—Madam, you may follow your own occaſions—I have none with an Old Woman.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: You are a Coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Your Servant—my Coach—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Muſt I loſe you Sir Courtly—ſtop Theif—ſtop Theif—

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! your Servant—my Coach you Dogs—

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Come my Lord, I ſee Patience in your Face, all may be well yet.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: How! Jilting already?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Promiſe I ſhall enjoy all and ſingular the Priviledges, Liberties, and immunities of an Engliſh Wife.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: All.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: That is to ſay, Ramble, Rant, Game, Dreſs, Viſit, Prate, Ogle, Kiſs—and—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Hold—hold—whether the Devil is ſhe running: Kiſs, kiſs—and—ſtop for Heavens ſake.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Kiſs, and before your Face; is it not the Prerogative of an Engliſh Wife? Surly, I owe thee a reward for Service, kiſs me.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: That's not to be borne.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Surly, I am thy Wife.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Hold—hold—for Heavens ſake—do not uſe me thus?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Then do not Rebel but practiſe obediently, the poſtures of an Engliſh Husband, before you are Liſted; Poiſe your Hat, draw your left Leg backward, bow with your Body, and look like an Aſs, whileſt I kiſs like a—Wife—Surly kiſs me.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: —If he does—

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: With all my Heart. If I kiſs thee, let the Devil Marry thee.
sp.stage: (he offers to kiſs her, and ſhe gives him a box o'th' Ear.)

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: And the Devil kiſs thee, cou'dſt thou think any Woman wou'd ſuffer thy face to come near her, but ſome Dairy Milk, to curdle her Milk?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Hoh! hoh! What a ſociety o' Gotam's are here, to laugh at Man for miſſing a Woman? had I Married her, as my Lord Wiſe-acre intends to do, I had deſerv'd to ha' been laught at, for a Coxcomb, and a Cuckold, as he will be in few Days.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Ay, you are all Whores, Pox on you, all Whores.
sp.stage: Enter Hothead and all the Servants.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Did you ſend for us?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Yes, do you ſee where my Siſter is?

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: By what witch craft was this?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Do not you remember a Vizard you turn'd out o' Doors?

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Was it you?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Even the ſame.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Then you deſerve to be turn'd out o' Doors again.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: But what do you deſerve Sir? that not only turn'd my Siſter out o' Doors—but let Mr. Teſtimony—pick her up for a Wench.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Oh! Dog—oh! Rogue—

sp.speaker: Teſ.
sp.p: I am no Rogue—a Man may fall, and be Godly in the main—I am ſatisfied in my Spirit, I am a Godly Man—

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: —Here's a Rogue—Sirrah—Sirrah—

sp.speaker: Teſ.
sp.p: Perſecution—Perſecution—Papiſt—do—kick the Godly, kick the Proteſtants out o' Kingdom—do Papiſt—I ſee what you wou'd be at—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: So Couſin now I have done with ſpyes—you may follow your own buſineſs, if you have any—

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Buſineſs? yes I have buſineſs, and will have buſineſs as long as there is a Fanatick in the Kingdom, and ſo farewell—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I am now convinced, Vertue a Womans only guard. If ſhe be baſe Metal, to think by Chimiſtry, to turn her into Gold,

l.hi: Is a vain dream of what we never ſee,
And I'le proclaim to all—It cannot be.

div.head: A SONG to be Sung in Dialogue between a Man and a Woman in the Third Act, to Sir Courtly Nice, at his firſt appearance.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: OH! be kind, my Dear, be kind,
Whilſt our Loves and we are Young.
We ſhall find, we ſhall find
Time will change the Face or Mind;
Both will not continue long.
Oh! be kind, my Dear, be kind.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.l: No, I Love, and fear to looſe you,
Therefore 'tis I muſt refuſe you,
When I've yielded you my Crown
You'l no more Obedience own.
No, I Love, and fear to looſe you
Therefore 'tis I muſt refuſe you.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: The Fair by kindneſs Reign,
By cruelty Deſtory.
If you can Charme with the Pain
Of Love, then what can you do with the Joy?
The Fair by kindneſs Reign,
By cruelty Deſtroy.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.l: I fear to yield, but cannot deny.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: If you do not I ſhall die.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.l: So ſhall I.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: So ſhall I.

sp.speaker: Chorus together.
sp.l: Then come to Joy—come to Joy,
Better Love than we ſhou'd die.
Come to Joy, come to Joy.

div.head: A Dialogue Sung between an Indian Man and Woman, in the Fourth Act, to Farewel, Violante, Crack. Being an imitation of a Song, Sung by ſome Natives of India, before the late King.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: THou lovely Indian Sea of Charms,
I'd envy no Jaw-waw alive
Might I be ſo, bleſt to dive
In thy ſoft yielding Arms

l.hi: With a Jimminy, Gomminy, whee-whee, whee.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.l: I wou'd if you'd be true,
But when you've done
You'l be gone,
And throw me of with a Shooh-ſhooh, ſhooh.

l.hi: And a migotty, magotty, migotty, magotty,

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: No, no, my other Females all
Yellow, Fair or Black,
To thy Charmes ſhall proſtrate fall,
As every kind of Elephant does
To the White Elephant Buitenacke.
And thou alone ſhall have from me

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.l: The great Jaw-waw that Rules our Land,
And pearly Indian Sea
Has not ſo abſolute Command,
As thou haſt over me.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Thou alone ſhalt have from me

l.hi: Whee, whee, whee, whee, whee, whee.
